text:
Appearance: Molasses brown body that looks quite black once in the glass. Decent 2 finger head with minimal lacing and fades gradually. A tiny bit weak IMO.

Smell: Nice clean aroma of coffee, semi-sweet chocolate and some hops. A touch of sweetness rounds things out.

Taste: A good roasted feel. Good, solid coffee presence with a slight hint of fruit (dried?) maybe cherries or strawberries. A nice and mild sweet taste. A touch of bitterness at first then as it warms, its all malt. Really good.

Mouthfeel: Smooth but i found the carbonation a little high. It calms down though as it warms. Coats the mouth with ease. Medium body not more.
Pours black with tan head. A strong coffee and chocolate aroma. A chocolate and coffee taste with roasted malts. A dry roasted malt and coffee aftertaste.

Bottle had during another Cowboy victory. Poured a black with a small head. Aroma is lots of dark roasted malt, coffee, vanilla bean. Light sweetness, light bitter. Slight semi-dry taste. Medium bodied. Creamy texture. Taste is dark roasted malt, slight cocoa, coffee notes. Pretty good stuff.

This stout poured a deep black colour with a brown, creamy head. Little lacing. Scents include a little wine, trace amour of whiskey, caramel and smoke. First swig was very tasty but a little bit thin on the palate. Flavours of burnt malts and brown sugar with some smoke and coffee. Finish is burnt and delicious.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at the brewery. Comes almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of malt and chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, dark fruit, caramel, and some coffee. Nice.
From a 12 oz bottle. Pours a deep cola brown with an ecru head. Aroma of tasted oats. Flavors of licorice and leather. Bitter roast finish.
Pours a black-brown from a tap. Somewhat cola-y, chocolate wafer in a beer glass. Good beer.
Very dark brown pour, small brown head. Aroma of chocolate, cocoa. Taste follows, note of bitter coffee. Okay.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle with a best by of 04/24/2016. 
Aroma has a moderate chocolate and roast character. Some low caramel and toffee notes. Moderate dark fruit esters with plum, cherry and floral notes. Light hop notes. 
Pours black, but with dark brown hues and a medium sized, fairly thick, light mocha head with decent retention as it slowly recedes. Light lacing and medium small legs. 
Flavor has a medium sweetness with balanced chocolate and roast. Some dark fruit notes of plum, cherry and raisin with some caramel and toffee. Medium bitterness with a medium light woody, herbal hop note. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a nice, traditional American stout. Some hop notes with balanced chocolate and roast. Medium fruit and floral esters as well.

Fizzy black pour, with an airy buildup of mocha hued bubbles. Tangy fruit aroma of raspberry, black cherry, black mission fig. Lactic tartness mingles with chocolate and baked graham crust sweetness, underneath. The ample, if guarded, malt depth becomes apparent with some warming, and these graham notes become the focal point. Lightly spiced flavor offers a melange of cinnamon, clove, and anise detailing the subtle dark malt, and these notes affect a cold, herbal sensation through the nose as well. No acrid malt, or soapiness, but its watery, and theres not enough density to the malt ultimately. The palate is nearly ruined by a violent over carbonation issue, and while a little air and a lot of time make it softer, it can never be described as texturally pleasing.  Brief, distantly fruity finish, astringent coffee grounds far out.

Chilled. Bomber served into tulip. Big, fluffy head is gone quick. Very little lacing. Roasted malt aromas. Taste is lightly sweet with some bitterness. Notes of chocolate. Some coffee and vinilla. Moderate carbonation. Medium bodied. Smooth texture. A pretty good stout but idk about award winning.
Chocolate notes and a bit of milk. Dark color. Smooth mouth but not velvety. Not bitter and not sweet. Tap

Petite bouteille achetée à Portland. Robe de stout et tête beige qui ne meurt jamais. Nez chocolaté et fruité avec des raisins et joliment touchée par quelque chose qui sapparente à lanis. Goût de chocolat modérément doux avec une pointe houblonnée comme une herbe parfumée et même boisée. Retour bien senti des fruits bleus. En bouche, un corps de moyenne densité avec un pétillement normal et une texture comme de la petite crème. Une finale houblonnée bien fidèle à ce style de bière jadis brassée pour les grandes traversées de locéan.

Large head that fades quickly. Minimal lacing. I also picked up on a sweet bourbon like aroma. Smooth and somewhat light body for a stout. Not overly complex but well done. Sweet and roasty with a subtle at most bitterness in the finish. Enjoyable stout.

Type: 12-oz. bottle
Glass: Stone Ruination pint glass
From: Beer Advocates SteveB24
Price: N/A
Purchased: N/A; Received on Feb. 7, 2015
Consumed: Feb. 18, 2015
Misc.: Best by February 2015

Thanks Steve!

Poured a pitch black color with two fingers of frothy, tan head that dissipated rather quickly. Poor lacing on the sides. Minimal retention. (Sight - 3.25)

First smell was some kind of liquor. First thought was bourbon, but that might have been more of a wish. Probably Baileys Irish Cream. Also purple grape, dark fruit, plum, raisins, pure dark chocolate, some roasted coffee beans, roasted toffee and dark caramel. Very nice on the nose. (Smell - 4.38)

Taste was just as good. Got dark fruit, plum, purple grape, fig, raisins, dark chocolate, sugary chocolate syrup and toffee. (Taste - 4.25)

Full body. Oily-to-creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long, smooth finish. (Feel - 4.38)

I couldnt believe how good this was, especially for the style. Very tasty. (Overall - 4.25)

4.24 94 A-
Smoky and smooth with slight coffee notes. Closer to medium body. Not a lot of complexity.

Bottle at patriots place for holiday lunch with friends. Pours deep brownish black small head. Nose is chocolate and coffee. Tastes of Cocoa powder, malt, coffee grinds, malted milk balls, and slight oily texture. Nice lingering slightly biter finish.
UPDATED: FEB 15, 2015 12oz bottle pours deep, dark black with brown clingy, lasting head. Nice lacing as this quickly disappears. Toasted and chocolatey goodness. This is first-class stout.
12 oz bottle from Giant Eagle in Pittsburgh. Deserves every bit of the high praise it merits. One of the best stouts Ive ever had.

Bottle- pours deep muddy black, dense brown ring of head. Nice lacing. Nose if chocolate, roasted malts, molasses, and raisins. A bit thin on the palate. Flavors of burnt toast, chocolate, molasses, dark fruits. Interesting stout that has some nice characteristics but lacking depth

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Come on now, this is a stout I could use with any one of 3 three great foods that I like, according to the summary of the beer that I just read. Its a very narcissistic description - talk about patting oneself on the back! - but nevertheless, flavor color texture etc all live up to the claims, so according to the Vodka4Blood Beer Tasting Institute (donations accepted!) I pronounce this stout exceptional!
Very much to-style Dry Stout. Cocoa, roasted coffee grounds bitterness, not detectably sweet, medium bodied. Tasty stuff.

Bottle from cpetrone-thanks, Chris! Deep black, almost opaque with huge slow fading foamy head. Nose is dark roast malts, light smokiness. Taste is bitter dark malts, lots of carbonation on this one. Bitter dark chocolate finish.
12 oz bottle pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and toffee. Taste is coffee and malts.

Bottle from Julios. Sweet chocolate aroma, dark pour with frothy head and no lacing. Roasted malts with milk chocolate dark fruit notes and some very mild lactic notes. Full mouthfeel. This was delightful.

Drought, inky black with small tan foamy head, slight roasted malt aroma, low carbonatio, strong alcohol taste overriden by toasted malt flavor, long finish with a burnt aftertaste. Fine brew but the alcohol taste is not fully masked, which is surprising for a beer with less than 9% alcohol content.

Very good dark opaque pour w/ a beautiful mocha head that slowly dwindles while leaving nice lacing. The taste is interesting not quite roasty but an odd bitterness is left on the tongue. Definitely not your traditional stout but Im not sure this completely works for me!

Great showing for style. Pours black will with great mocha head and lacing. Creamy texture. Some roast and chocolate with equal sweet and dark elements. Roast a little over caramelized for style but still a food beer overall. Tap at Black Squirrel.

Pours almost black with a moderate, tan head and average lacing. Nose is malty. Taste is a touch on the bitter side with a bold complement of malt. Notes of burnt toast and toffee. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Very nice brew!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown, no lace. 
Chemical, cleaning product smell. 
Medium body, thin texture, well carbonated, not much heat, aflavorfull, avg length. 
Sour, then moderatly bitter with a hint of sweetness, pp in finish. 
Roast flavors dominate, as expected, coffee, a suggestion of herbs. 



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I was really surprised to sign on RateBeer and see how highly rated this beer was. It struck me as bland and sweet. Flavor is sweet, with little bitterness or sourness, mouthfeel is flat and thick, syrupy. Not much carbonation. I suppose if people rate this beer on smoothness alone, I could see its appeal. But I found it uninteresting. The aroma was featureless. Theres little roast or hops evident in the aroma, only a fairly plain malt. This was an unremarkable beer that I drank quickly and could forget. About the only thing I think it has going for it is that the medium-high alcohol content is well-masked, but I think its masked more by the sugar than anything else. I thought this beer way too sweet. Im not a huge fan of this style of beer, but I thought this a particularly poor example of it as well, and Im completely perplexed as to how this beer is so highly rated and has won so many awards.

12 oz. bottle.  Pour is a classic stout, jet black,  khaki head with decent lacing.  Smell is the classic coffee/dark chocolate with notes of marshmallow.  Taste is mellower with coffee and bakers chocolate up front and slightly sweet milk chocolate towards the end.  Finish is clean with some faint hops and subtle lingering flavors.  Good example of the style and easy to drink.
Pitch black pour, aint much head here. Dark malt, hop, oak, coffee and chocolate on the nose. Taste is coffee, oak, malt and dark espresso on the back end. A good clean stout

Black pour with a half inch thick frothy off white head and spotty to thick lacing .... deep roasted aroma and dark chocolate .... taste is very dry with a nice deep roasted malt, light coffee and dark chocolatey flavors ..... very dry,  and thin on the mouthfeel .... abv hidden well and very highly drinkable dry stout .... medium bodied which only makes it even more sessionable

A dark brown pour with about finger of lacing tan head. Aroma is roasted with chocolate, coffee, and hints of bitter wood. Taste is well rounded and with a full body. A moderate sweet flavor with a medium duration and a slight bitter finish. Overall a great beer!

Pour is very dark brown, bordering black, with a light caramel head and some large bubbles. Nose is heavy coffee roast, slightly muddled roasted malt, a bit chalky and ashy, faint chocolate. Taste follows suite, heavy roasted malt and coffee, lighter chalky ash and a but more chocolate. Medium body, assertive carbonation, crisp dry finish with lingering roast.
Pours dark with a creamy head. Nice roasted malt aroma. Fairly complex with notes of dried fruit and a smooth finish. Well made beer.

Wow, so unexpected from a brewer that isnt very well known, but they do this one right. Black oily pour into the pint glass, tiny head that is gone in a flash. Almost an Imperial Stout aroma with the coffee and vanilla, but no alcohol burn, in fact this might be the smoothest dry stout Ive had. Finish is wonderful.
Very light in flavor for a stout. I am not saying it is bad but there is nothing that stands out

Bottle 650ml.
Pours black with medium diminishing brown head. Good lacing. Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee. Taste is of chocolate, roasted malt, very slight bitterness, alcohol. Palate: Carbonation is a tad prickling for the style. Medium-full bodied. Oily texture. Overall: Good. Not really complex, but fairly drinkable.

Thx goes to ferris for sharing this ancient bottle (99ish). Oxydized goodness, plum, old raspberries, dates, syrupy goodness. I breathed it in for 45 mins. Old ass tasty oxidized greatness, light mocha, weak biscuit, different fruit, oily. Terrible description. Enjoyable beer!

Bottle to flute
Aroma is predominantly Kerrs molasses kiss, caramel, and soy. Dark brown, thin tan head. Milk chocolate, soy, burnt malts.

Bottle - Vintage old (1999?) - Smells like a tootsie roll, tons of cocoa, molasses and chocolaty goodness. Jet black with a thin brown head. Chocolate and as it smells exactly. Sweet and not sour at all, which is great considering its age. Love it, thanks to CapFlu.
Robust malt aroma with a light amount of chocolate. Black color with a small tan head. Mild beginning with a bitter middle and sweet finish. Palate is a little light for a stout.

Smooth stout one of my favorites. 
  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle thanks to Micheal! Pours near black with a brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of dark grains and roasted malts with a decent amount of dryness. Flavor has more sweet dark grains with roasted malts and just a hint of dryness in the finish.

12 oz with no date purchased at whole foods. First time I've seen this in PA. Pours a dark black but not thick which is good for a dry stout. Little head and zero lacing. Dry malty and cocoa aroma. Mouthfeel is light with a bit too much carb. Taste is very solid. Dark fruit berries very mild smoke and roast coffee. Almost slight my Belgian. No alcohol whatsoever very well done. A classic that more than holds its own with today's competition. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From the 650 ml. bottle with no bottling/expiration date. Nice dark brown to black pour with a few dabs of ruby red hues. Full beige head. Aroma of chocolate malts, yeast, and toasted bread/biscuit. Pleasant. The body is medium to full but also slightly acidic. Again, like the nose, I get chocolate in the taste with a mild to moderate bitterness and dryness at the end. Overall it is a pleasant and drinkable beer and I hope you get to try it.
Bottle. Black, thin head. Dry stout with lots of roasted flavors. Overall good bit just with a little too much carbonation.

650 ml bottle

This has been sitting around long enough so I cracked it open one night. It is a great stout that I should have drunk a bit sooner. While still fresh this is so good that I would have consumed it immediately. Dont make the same mistake yourself.

Aroma / Appearance - The oily black base slides easily down the sides of the glass. A thin mocha head lasts for quite a while. Chocolate, raspberries, coffee, and smoke meld with ease into a chewy texture. Solid and robust it fills the air with goodness.

Flavor / Palate - Plums, coffee, and dark fruit stick to the throat. Almost as sweet as a lightweight imperial stout the texture is filling from start to finish. It avoids being sticky and saccharine. Enjoy it as long as possible before you move on to your next tick.

12oz bottle thanks the daveymac! Pours a rich black color with a finger of creamy mocha head. Aroma of chocolate malt, roasted coffee, ash, and a hint of vanilla. Taste mimics the nose. Very roasty, chocolatey, notes of ash, burnt toast, and hints of caramel and vanilla extract.
Bottle thanks to adnielsen: Poured deep oily black with no head to light bubbles. Aroma is roasted malts and light coffee. Taste is strong coffee bean with roasted malts.

Bottle shared at a tasting at Ariels place. Pours black with a nice beige head, aroma of roast, chocolate, coffee, malt, some smoke, flavor is dry with coffee, roast, nice sweetness, bitterness, medium bodied, nice
Very dark brown, medium tan head. Aroma chocolate, coffee, roasted malt. Medium body. Flavor sweet caramel up front with roasty flavors and mocha, and a dry malty finish. Pretty good.

Draft at Farmers Cabinet. Opaque pour yhat shows up as a clear ruby under bright light. Starts with a thick khaki foam. Minimum lace. Very creamy body. French roast coffee. Dark chocolate mousse. Liquorice. Slight burnt meat (but not rauch.) Balanced flavors. Very good mouthfeel. Otherwise somewhat standard, but very well done. Great dry Stout.

Bottle at home. Pours opaque black with a medium, frothy beige head, medium retention with light lacing. Aroma is chocolate, roast and coffee malt, prunes and dates, and light earthy hops. Flavor is dark malt dominant, light hops and bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks zvikar. Black. Slightly roasty and chocolate aroma, a little coffee sourness and some ink in the mouth, full body and sourish finish.
Bottle at Damicos. Pours a black color with off white head. Aroma of slight roast, chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Sweet vanilla taste with roasty coffee and chocolate. Creamy and tasty.

Bottle. Poured a black with a small head. Aroma is lots of dark roasted malt, coffee, vanilla bean. Light sweetness, light bitter. Slight dry chaulky taste. Medium bodied. Creamy texture. Taste is dark roasted malt, slight cocoa, coffee notes. Pretty good.
Robust malt aroma with a light amount of chocolate. Black color with a small tan head. Mild beginning with a bitter middle and sweet finish. Palate is a little light for a stout

Pours dark black/brown into english pint glass with 1 finger head. Nose is coffee, cocao, chocolate cake, dirt. Mouthfeel is medium body, slightly sticky. Taste is chocolate, coffee, cream, roasty, earthy, maple, caramel. Finish has mild bitterness and some light hop notes. A solid stout. Would love to see a coffee, chocolate, or barrel aged version to enhance some of whats already there.

At a tasting, thanks zvikar, very dark brown to black, aroma of coffee, very dark bread, some woodiness and a touch of milk chocolate, dominant flavour of roasted coffee with some cherries, light bodied but quite balanced. Very nice.
Drank from a snifter, Medium body, and slightly roasty. This was a very nice stout. I generally drink IMP stouts, and this should not be confused with one. Very smooth and tasty.

8/16/13 bottle from RW shared with Dan . Drank out front. slight coffee on the nose, Taste is typical stout, but nothing special. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks zvikar. Black, not opaque, with a light brown head. Nice roasty aroma with a bit of coffee and light dark chocolate notes. Pleasant bittersweet roasty flavor with some coffee. Medium-bodied.

Bomber (after climbing Beech Mountain with the family). Pours a deep brown with a large tan head of foam. Aromas are nice and stouty... Roasted malts, licorice, a bit of charcoal and a hint of cream. Flavor is similar, but a little thin lots of licorice and leather. I wish the mouthfeel was a little fuller, but this is a very nice stout.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle from Brewtopia. Pours black with a thin khaki head. Roasted chocolate malt on the nose. The chocolate on the tongue is ice up front but it fades a bit as the beer warms. Nice amount of bitterness on the finish to keeps things tight.

Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of coffee and roasted malts. The taste has a dry finish but doesnt make you run for a glass of water like most. Smooth mouthfeel and proper carbonation. A great representation of the style.
Nice chocolate stout, notes of coffee dark chocolate, nice tan head, proper lacing, smooth finish.
Aroma is roasted malts, fruit and a hint of acidity. The flavor is roasted malts, dark fruit/raspberries, mild sweet notes and an acidic finish.
Some coffee on the nose, but not overwhelming. Taste is typical stout, but not in your face or overwhelmingly so. Nice and surprisingly refreshing.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a dark brown with a beige head of foam. Aroma is ashy and roasty. Tastes toasty sweet. A little thin.

Rich black color; Medium body; Aroma of toasted malt, grain/hops, dark chocolate, & coffee; Flavor of roasted/burnt malt, caramel, hops, coffee, and some dark chocolate; Finish is dry and slightly tangy; Quite good.

Poured from 12 oz. bottle.

Opaque, near black with small, creamy brown head with very good lacing.

Mild aroma of roasted malt, toffee, coffee peat and caramel.

Taste of roasted malt, light peat, coffee, milk chocolate and caramel.

Medium/light body and low/medium carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a rich thick deep burnt umber with a big frothy three finger mocha foam. On the nose its roasted chocolate, lactic earth and a hint of peat. The palate follows the nose nicely with a big rich round mouthfeel. Nice balance of flavors and a lingering roasty earth finish.

22oz bottle from radarsock. Very dark brown color, almost black. Thin brown head, fades to minimal, leaves just a little bit of lace.. Good bitter taste. Lightly sweet finish. Awesome roasty flavor, good dark chocolate, little dark fruit, nice toasty malts, some herbal hops, light smokiness. Medium to bigger body. Good chewy body, but dry texture. Light to moderate carbonation. Indeed, a very impressive stout.

Poured from a small bottle into a trumpet glass to drink.  The beer had a cloudy black color with a slight brown hue, and a very small foamy tan head with short retention, and light-to-average lacing and cling.  Its aroma featured roasty malt and caramel, and was a bit smokey too, along with touches of earthy and grainy hops, and lighter tones of coffee and maybe some chocolate.  Its taste was somewhat grainy and bitter with a light caramel malt sweetness, and some touches of chocolate and coffee, but was a bit underdeveloped overall.  The body was lightly creamy, but a bit watery and wet, with a medium mouthfeel and lower carbonation.  Thank you for the beer, Siobhan.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2017 It pours a dark brown and leaves a foamy off white head. Minimal lacing occurs and spider webs apart. The smell is roasty between coffee and chocolate notes. The taste.takes those flavorings to make it sweet. The palate is about a medium to heavy with nothing harsh on the tongue, slightly sof and creamy. Id say its fairly drinkable. Overall, this is a good standard American stout that I would gladly come back to.

Pours black with a medium tan head that quickly dissipated.  Aroma is roast, dark chocolate and coffee.  Taste is sweet with acidic/tart undertones.  Finishes sweet and dry, almost crisp.  Medium bodied with a thin clean texture.

(Bottle). Black complexion with dissipating tan head with very little lacing. Well roasted malts dominate flavor with elements of black coffee.  Could be easy to session in cold months. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from James - thanks!  Black pour with a dark tan head fading to a slick of foam.  Aroma is dry, somewhat thin chocolate with roast.  Taste is roasty chocolate with light sweet malt, coffee, and some minimal hop bitterness.  Clean, easy drinking dry stout.  Enjoyable.

Very sincerely happy that my local grocery store stocks these by the truckload. Pours an oily dark brown with a trim khaki head not even a fingernail in length. Aromas of pancake batter, rose pedals, tobacco, roast, English yeast and some ginger notes. Tastes predominately of semi-dark chocolate, noble hops, burnt rubber, ash and yeast. Caramel and almonds by swallow. What can I say? Im a true follower of this stuff,

22 oz. bomber:  This one pours an opaque, very dark brown color.  There was a very small tan head on it that didnt linger long.  Almost no lacing.  Nice nose.  Pretty full or aroma, but mainly chocolate and roasted malts.  Some coffee notes also.  The taste is good.  Roasty, chocolate, and coffee mainly in the taste.  A very nice stout!

11/1/12. 22oz bottle thanks to nulledge! Nice black pour with a small khaki head. Really nice aroma with coffee, cream, and chocolate. The flavor is very nice as well, also showing plenty of coffee, chocolate, and a hint of sweet cream. Really tasty stuff!

Poured black with a thin light-tan head.  Aroma is very chocolaty with some coffee, vanilla, and nuts.  Taste is very malty and roasted with milk chocolate.    Slightly creamy  with good burnt malt flavors.  A tad nutty with vanilla.  Finish is nice and roasted with a long aftertaste of roasted nuts and chocolate.  Very good!

12oz....sample from bottle. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malts, campfire, sweet brown sugar, and a bit of a hop note. Drinking is insanely smooth and delish! Roasted goodness throughout with vanilla, caramel, chocolate, coffee, and much more. Damn, damn good brew here
Bottle. Pours near black with a beige head. Roasted malts, chocolate, medium sweetness, with a roasted malty finish. Good stuff.

A: Pours a viscous looking pitch black with a fluffy khaki color head. Retention is awesome.

S: Mellow but complex. Notes of coffee, lactose, cocoa, and fruit. A bit of roasted toffee as well

T: Wow, really great flavors. Very very mellow and smooth. Light coffee, lactose, a bit of sweetness, dark fruit and berries, cocoa, chocolate, and no bitterness

MF/D: Full bodied, viscous, and creamy. Alcohol completely hidden, and easily drinkable.

Notes: Must try!

taste is an 8.5.
black beer with a dark brown head.
prominent in aroma and taste is chocolate & cherries.to taste,chocolate on the front end,cherries on the back end.
very nice!

22oz bomber bottle, purchased from Liquor Locker, Southwest Harbor (I think), consumed in April 2010. Very dark brown. Rapidly disappearing tan head. Light bodied for a stout and quite dry. Some roast malt. Very drinkable but generally I thought this was just a little short of impact and depth. Judging from the much higher scores that seem the norm for this beer, I wonder whether my bottle wasnt in the best shape. Flagged for re-rate.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2013 Roasty and lightly floral aroma.  Simple, attractive label.  Dark pour with a decent head.  A very enjoyable stout - sweet, flavorful, smoky, and a little acidic, with coffee and pumpernickel flavors.  Smooth on the palate.  Downgraded a little in 2013 after a sugary pint that did not make as good an impression.

This beer appears a near black shade with a nice, big head atop the beer. Retention and lacing are very nice, as well. This beer is very easy to drink. I already want to go out and buy more. This is quite possibly my new favorite lower abv stout. Roasted malts with a hint of coffee and perhaps even a splash of chocolate comprise the aromas and taste. Alcohol is hidden extremely well. Highly recommended.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. Poured dark black with brown head. The aroma is a little lack luster, soft chocolate character, and roasted malt. The flavor is chocolate, caramel, slight acidity. I found this beer to be boring.

On draft at Pony Bar with Andy and James. Pours black with reddish hue. Aroma is chocolate and a little roast. Palate is more of the same with a little roastiness but a very light mouthfeel for a stout. Despite it being thin, its very rich and flavorful. Enjoyed.

Draft with. Rendan and Andrew at pony bar. Pours a deep, deep brown with thin brown lacing. Aroma is roasted chocolate malts. Mouthfeel is creamy with notes of chocolate, coffee, smoke and roast. Nice.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a small tan head that left a touch of lacing. The aroma was dryish and roasty with notes of anise and coffee. The flavor was dry, bitter and roasty with sharp floral hops and coffee. Medium length dry and roasty finish with lingering coffee. Medium body though a bit thin for a stout. Eh.

Bottle thanks to phillybeer7779.  Clear brownish black pour, thin light tan head.  Dry roasty stout, a bit of cocoa, burnt coffee, and ash.  Its decent, but overall its fairly average.  Not a bad thing, its just not very interesting.

Not a favorite stout for me. Pour was near black with little head and weak lacing. Body could be a bit thicker, but not bad. The taste is odd, mostly malt, yet there is a flavor that I cannot quite identify, but it kinda tastes like soap. Funny how the reviews are so contradictory; maybe inconsistent brewing? I cannot say I would try this again. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22oz bottle from the City Market Onion River Co-Op in Burlington, VT. Pours a black body with a finger-width, creamy, dark brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is solid with rich dark chocolates, a light hard roast, a hint of tobacco smoke, a bit of a chewy cookie malt, vanilla cream, and a light earthy hopping. Flavor is slightly sweet cookie malts and rich chocolates up front with a roasty, slightly leafy tobacco backing. A moderate earthy hopping alongside the roasts with a bit of a cream and a touch of dark fruit notes. Finishes with some tobacco and roasts as well as a medium earthy hopping leaving this dry and moderately bitter, but balanced nicely with the smooth malts. Lengthy aftertaste following a medium-full, creamy, smooth body and a soft, moderate carbonation. Overall, a really nice dry stout. Very smooth, soft, and creamy body with a nice chocolate and cookie malt backing. Balanced roastiness with some leafy tobaccos and a decent hop backing. Good beer.

Bottle. 25.4 oz, Pours a pitch black opaque with a thin, slightly lacy beige head. Aroma of cocoa nibs, cream, milk, roast, esspresso beans, and hints of toasted almonds. Full bodied with an insanely rich, velvety palate. Finishes with a lovely bit of warming in the belly. Great dry stout.

nicely smooth upfront with flavors of cola, vegetable broth and an interesting dark cherry hint like what you would find in a cherry cola. frothy suds with just a touch of charred wood and a bitterness in the suds. light malt aroma of brown gravy.
Bottle. Almost black, thin brown edge head. Aroma of roasted coffee, toast, dark cocoa powder. Taste is coffee grounds, dark chocolate, malted milk balls. Very nice.

Pours black with a creamy light tan head.  Nose is roasted malt, some dusts of coffee beans and dark chocolate, unsweetened.  Earth, twig.  Mouth is super dry, total unsweetened dark cocoa powder, roasted malts, weird almost salt, ocean flavors on the finish.  Plant like and oceanic, dry as all get out.

Great aroma of chocolate and coffee. One of the blackest stouts I can remember. Not very heady, perhaps due to being bottled. Big flavor of bittersweet chocolate, with woody, smokey, and syrup notes all over. Wide body, with classic Irish dryness in full affect. A great stout I would recommend to all.

Really rich aroma.  Strong mocha note.  Just a very light touch of roasted malt. Black strap molasses too.  Pitch black, opaque beer with modest but long-lasting tan head.  Alcohol is well managed. Sweet start with a dry finish.  Lots of chocolate in the flavor.  Very slight coffee.  Brief bitter note at the swallow.  Nicely carbonated.  Maybe just a hair thin in the body.  Overall, a beer I would purchase again and again.  Highly drinkable and nice depth of flavor.

Bottled 12oz (NYC)
Dark opaque black color, midsized creamy beige head. Aroma of coffee, licorice and burnt bread. Medium-bodied. Lots of licorice, burned malty flavor. Lots of dark malts, less hops. Semi-sweet. Suprised to see so high points for this.
bomber shared by jsprime. black,  tan head. great dark malt, coffee, chocolate. dry, chalky. highly drinkable. great stout.

Bottle from sanborn13.  Pours black with fluffy off-white head.  Soft roasted malt and mild sweetness.  Flavor is smooth roast, slightly acidic, followed by light cream/brown sugar, and finishing dry.  Not much linger on the flavor, little roast.  Relatively thin, but sessionable.
Bottle, pours black, pretty good, it has a light head, this one is quite dry, it has a nice body and good flavour

Bomber bottle that poured a dark black color, aromas of chocolate, toffee, coffee, and no hop presance anywhere.  Flavors of milk chocolate, caramel, splash of coffee, and bitter chocolate at the end, I liiked this beer a lot.
Shared bottle with Timfoolery. Tasted of dark chocolate. Just wasnt quite sweet enough for me. Nice complex flavoring and smooth on the palate, but was just missing something.

Bottle from Sean in trade. This one was excellent in the palate and consistency. The flavor was a rich version of typical dry stouts, even some slight sweetness. Chocolate and coffee flavors were present and nicely tamed in the brew. I can see why this beer was rated so highly in the 1990s, however there are significantly more dry stouts out there now to win gold at the WBC. Good beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottle with a big thanks to mkgrenwal.   pours black with a huge long lasting frothy tan brown head.   aroma of dry roasted coffee, tootsie rolls, cocoa, and milk chocolate.   buncha dry roasted coffee in the taste, hazelnuts, coffee, cream.  tasty.   nice and dry.     pretty solid allaround.   like.

This beer rates pretty damn high.  Which honestly I dont get.   Its a nice decent drinkable stout but its not mindblowing.  Maybe Im wanting to much these days, I dont know.  It tastes session able but really its almost 7% abv so its not really session able.  Maybe I had an old bottle or something.
A really nice stout. Not too bitter, not too sweet, not too thick, not to thin. Its nice and easy drinking. Not a monster, Not mind blowing but good and easy.
Bottle. Deep black color > creamy looking half inch head that lasts > very rich but not overly sweet. Deliciously balanced and easy drinking. Better then I expected. a fine stout
bottle. pours night black with minimal thin white head. aroma is standard oat,and roasted malt. taste is thin nice flavor but for me was just a normal stout very good classic example.

Pours black but really a deep deep red. Nose is breads coffee, light chocolate, lactose, and sweet malts. Good roast and coffee flavor sweet at first then dries out. medium body and smooth. nice beer especially for the abv. g

On the 9th day of Christmas, Chalsks beer gods gave to me...Pours dark chocolate in color with a decent caramel bubbly head. The aroma a bit smokey with a rich almost coffee grind aroma. The flavor has notes of coffee and roasted malts on a lighter body. It is simple in a delicious way, a great drinking stout.

[1pt6floz bottle courtesy of cgarvieuk] Black pour, decent tan head. Some chocolate on the aroma, but quite a subdued nose. Some cardboard in evidence. Decent amount of carbonation. Roasty on the palate, although the finish is quite thin. Doesnt taste 6% [20122011]

Pours a dark brown colour with a thin, light tan head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate and alcohol. Similar flavours although a little thin. Moderate carbonation and an oily mouth-feel. Very well masked alcohol. Nice chocolatey linger.

Bottlet at home ... deep black ... thin tan head ... soft mellow caramel malt nose ... over fizzy .. way over fizzy ... odd roast malt ... light herbalness ... ligth smokeyness ... not working for me at all im afraid...

This is a bottle of the good version of this beer (pre-2009 I believe) with the cartoony label. Anyway, all I know is that. If I had to guess, Id say its a 2008 vintage. The new version was disappointing. Poured into a snifter.

3.5 A: Black color. A little over a finger of frothy/fizzy hybrid head. Retention could be better and no lacing is left.

4.5 S: For a dry stout, this is simply dripping with maltiness. Tons of caramel, a soft roastiness, molasses and toffee, and some chocolate.

4.0 T: Tastes a lot like the nose with perhaps a touch more roast. Caramel, molasses, toffee, and chocolate. Pretty intense for the ABV.

4.0 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Could be a bit creamier, but not bad overall.

4.0 D: Good brew. They should brew this beer like they brewed the one Im drinking.
