Reviewed on: 10-05-2011 01:36:32
Bottle: pours dark black with a think tan head, nice roasty, chocolate aroma, taste is malty, chocolate, dry finish

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2011  bomber via trade with  BrentK THANKS!!   Great aromas - roasted stuffs, mmmm.  dark black pour; palate surprisingly thin?  flavor was well balanced - hit with tingly/fizzy hops right up front but malt, roasted, smoothed it out into enjoyable beer.  hints of chocolate as beer warmed.  nice..

22 oz. bottle (from notes- older label from >5 yrs. ago).  Pours a very dark brown with a medium sized beige head.  The aroma has roasted malts, dry dark chocolate and hints of coffee.  The flavor is roasted malts, dark chocolate, lighter coffee notes and some decent bitterness at the back.  Dry, but smooth.  Medium bodied.  This was a great example of a dry stout many years ago.  I have not had the new versions in the 12 oz. bottles, but I imagine that it would be difficult to beat.

Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass deep black, small head. Starts strong and malty, quite dry, roasty. Some hints of coffee and chocolate. Finish again drier, not very drinkable. Not my favourite.

A: Rich deep chocolate brown.. smallish khaki head with light lacing after the head quickly receded.

S: Mostly chocolate up front.. creamy milk chocolate and bitter dark chocolate... roasted malts fill things out

T: Again, chocolate is king here.. milk chocolate up front and a slightly bitter dark chocolate presence towards the finish... the roasted malts give off an almost baked flavor which is brownie/cake like... very nice

M: A bit thin... but smooth and enjoyable on the palate... nice clean finish.

O: I enjoyed this one... its not massive in flavor, but as a 6.7% dry stout it was nice (review from 2009)

Bottle: pour is murky brown with an expected fine bubbled khaki head ; the nose is roasted coffee and chocolate notes. The flavor profile begins with a hint of bitterness from the roasty coffee and hop bill; a cream from the head, and chocolate notes,  finishing again on the bitter side, while also feeling a bit dry, as expected. Its smooth, semi sweet, with a full mouthfeel.

3 oz. draft sample. Roasted coffee aroma. Poured black with a light cappuccino coloured head. Taste is roasted malts and a dark coffee bitterness. Body is medium and dry. Unlike many dry stouts this did not seem watery at all. Overall, what Guinness should be, but isnt.

Bottle from the brewery.  Pours like a stout (black, thin tan head), smells like a stout (roasty, just a hint of smoke, and a light bitterness), and feels like a stout (smooth, chocolatey, smoky).  Could be used for Beerademics 101 as the typical dry stout.  Well made.  (#4261, 9/21/2011)

12oz bottle, thanks to Matt (Reynolds314). Black with a nice tan creamy head. Lightly roasted malts, dry, no hint of alcohol, grains, bittersweet baking chocolate. Average body, bitterness that grows, highly carbonated (too much), slightly sweet and very dry ending, bit of anise as well. This beer will always have a special place in my heart since - tastes change but still its a very good introductory beer for those who want to try something dark.
Bomber.  Poured black with beige head.  Aroma is ash, coffee, nuts.  Taste is no sweetness, bittering roasty notes.  Palate is a bit thin and watery but a good dry stout.
bottle at Nor Easter in Provincetown. excellent stout. deep black pour, heavily roasted aroma with notes of coffee, olive brine, slight booze. Very balanced flavor, heavily roasted. Very good stuff

(bomber from Largiari, sampled 7/28/10). Black color. Medium tan head. Moderate roasted malt aroma, with light sweetness. Same flavor with light chocolate. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Soft to moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

Bottle shared with some friends over football. Dark black pour, creamy texture with very little head. Aroma has hints of chocolate, licorice, and a slight smoke presence. Flavor is obviously dry but still has a subtle sweet tone to it. Not too bad.

Courtesy of HOPSHUNTER, thanks Jason!! Bomber pours mahogany with mocha head. The modest aroma offers up dark roasted malts, some lactose like notes and a bit of chocolate. The taste begins a bit on the smoky side and then pulls up modest notes of chocolate and dark roasted malts. The smoke sensation may also be a sort of earthy quality mixing with faint oyster notes. Cool brew with rich flavors.
Bottle, pitch black with almost no head.... caramel and chocolate aroma..... the flavor is thin coffee, chocolate.. some bitterness ...

Bottle. Pours black with a medium tan head. The aroma is liquorice, hard roasted malt, coffee, light chocolate and some tobacco. The flavour is hard roasted, liquorice, light chocolate, tobacco and light coffee. Quite complex for the abv.
Aroma was of chocolate and caramel.  Taste was chocolate and caramel, was a little watery not as good a I thought it was going to be.

Bottle. Black appearance. Aroma was chocolate, caramel, some faint ash. The flavor followed, some molasses also in there, somewhat of a weak flavor. Mouthfeel was light and slightly on the watery side. Didnt meet the need out by the pit fire, and relative to the medals and high rating here, I was disappointed. But, it was better than the watery real ale.

Tasted on 7/24/11 from a 12oz bottle sent to me as an extra in a trade, there is no bottle date to be found.  Pours absolutely opaque black with a thin tan head that slowly recedes to nothing more than a decent collar, leaving just a touch of very thin residue along the inside of the glass.  The nose is very roasted with dark chocolate, coffee, a touch of cola, and just a hint of creamy lactose as well.  The flavor is almost exactly the same with dark malt, dark chocolate, and toast, along with just the lightest hint of vanilla lactose.  The body is medium with light carbonation and a long roasted malt and coffee finish.

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  The beer is a beautiful black color with tan head laying on top.  The aromas once warmed start to come out and you get notes of roasted malt and coffee.  The taste is similar, but I got a little carmel and some resiny molasses.  Body is spot on with a nice thick mouthfeel and average carbonation.  Overall, this is a very well done brew.

22 oz. bottle bought near Boston.  A nice very black with red stout appearance with a nice fluffy two finger tan head.  A nutty nose that also has roasted notes and molasses.  A nice thick smooth feel.  No one flavor dominates but milk chocolate and then bitterness lead.  Molasses, again.  At the finish a hint of hops tickles the tongue.  Nothing is huge here but this is a solid stout.  The feel goes a long way but the taste is very nice, too.

Black body with a thick beige foamy head. Smells of roasted malt, caramel, milk, with a touch of earthy notes. Milky flavour at first, replace by a strong,dry, almost metallic mouth finish. Aftertaste of hazlenuts and oatmeal. A world class dry stout. Its a shame its not distributated in Vermont and/or Quebec.
Bottle.  Pours very dark with a thin tan head.  Aroma and flavor are some chocolate, coffee, a bit of licorice.  Very rich, quite dry, a bit creamy.  A very tasty brew.

Bottle, purchased at Belfast Co-op -,Belfast, ME. Crisp complex dark malt aroma profile. Flavors were good and above average in depth and complex, with nuanced coffee, cocoa, and char tones. However, Im not sure the bottle I had really qualifies as a world class example. Good not amazing. Entered from my mobile device.

Bottle shared. A fine dark brown pour with a tanned latte coloured head that slowly. A nose that is dominated with coffee, roasted malts and a faint touch of laqurice. The mouthfeel is mild with a thin body when thinking of this as a stout. But it taste good and it has an refreshing effect. The taste is pretty roasted again with the coffee on top. A long fine finish with a pleasant bitterness and a  caramelish sweetness.

Solid stout, a bit rich for my liking, but very thick, chocolate tasting, a bit of coffee, have one to age which I am looking forward to, all in all an above average stout, not catching all the hype this is getting though.
Bottle. Black with a very thin light brown head. Nothing distinct in the aroma. Nice stout. A bit of bitterness. Some coffee flavour. Pretty solid and straight forward.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Buy Rite - Jersey City, 5/8/11


Aroma: This one has a fairly roasty nose, some coffee, wood, and chocolate

Appearance: The pour is pretty much black with a small brown head

Flavor: The taste is also rather roasted, almost burnt, lightly sweet and lightly bitter

Palate: The mouthfeel of this one is fairly creamy with a medium body and a dry roasted finish

Overall Impression: 
This was a pretty solid, but fairly one-dimensional stout.  The roasted (leaning toward the burnt side) malts are really the dominating component of this one.

Pitch black coloured body with a thick tall tan head with some nice bubbles. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, milk, a touch of peat and some light earthy notes - very nice and strong. Medium-bodied; Assertive caramel and milky flavour at first with a very dry and tanniny malt body showing some metal and light nuttiness. Aftertaste has a bit of hazlenuts, some oatmeal and a good dose of sweetness. Overall, a very well made beer that shows well and should be sampled if you can find it! I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from Liquor Outlet in Boonton, New Jersey on 10-October-2010 sampled at home after returning from Asia (read: no real good deep strong beers) on 24-April-2011.

Pours a black color with a small tan head. Lacing is present. Repeat, lacing is present. Coffee, roasted barley (same as coffee), slight maltiness
 in the nose. Malty, coffee taste. Mix that in with a bit of a sweet vanilla. Nice overall mouthfeel. A little bitter but balanced well.
Aroma of cocoa and iron.  Appears dark but not dirty with a small head.  Tastes of roasted chocolate.  Good with just a little of a metallic aftertaste.
nah, this dry stout is supposedly good, not for me. The main flavor in this stout is a plastic sweetness that tastes like dirty laundry water. Just pretty bad.

22 oz. bottle.  This is easily Bar Harbors best brew! I had a few others which are very unimpressive. THIS BREW would be the exception. Dark brown with a thick, full, tan head that left good lacing. Roasty,aroma with a hint of chocolate covered coffee beans.  Taste is coffee and chocolate dominating with roasted characteristics of each blended together very well. A nearly full to medium body.  I drank this 22 oz bottle with ease and then I wanted more!

The beer pours dark brown with a total lack of carbonation. No head at at all. 

The aroma is medium and super malty with notes of caramel, bread, and candied sugar. 

The taste is super boring and flavorless. The feel is light without any flavor or feel at all. The taste is totally dead until the very end where you get a hint of skunked coffee. 

no bueno at all.

24-0-11 bouteille: Noire opaque avec une petit filament de mousse beige. Arômes frais de café avec une touche dolives noires et de toasté. Bien balancée en saveurs, sans etre extravagante. Corps asser léger, avec une texture moyennement huileuse et légèrement épaisse. Saveurs légères de café et dolives noires avec une finale légèrement amer. Bonne stout asser classique et sans artifices.

Unknown vintage.  Suspected to be at least 2 years old.  The beer pours to a black body with a fizzy but lasting dark beige head.  The aroma is chocolate bars and has a nice malty component.  Roasted malts and sweetened condensed milk chocolate and oatmeal.  Like a delicious chocolate revel bar.  Speaking of those, this makes me want to make a batch sometime soon.  The flavor is deeply roasted chocolate malts and sweet milk chocolate and caramel.  I wouldnt say dry stout, as this is pretty sweet, but thats the marvel of this beer.  Its simply delicious.  Id buy it all the time if I lived in Maine.  The palate is mouthwatering, but also quenching at the same time.  Finish is very clean.  Makes me want more and more.  Substantial mouthfeel, but unbelievably clean.
black, hazy, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, full body, Tasted at Bina Osteria in Boston

Aroma:Smells of dark malt and a little cleaning chemicals. There is some sweetness in the aroma.

Appearance:Dark, opaque, nice head thats slightly off-white.

Taste:Lots of smokey flavor, with some dark malt. Theres a little hoppy bitterness present as well on the foretaste. The sweet smokey flavor lingers through the aftertaste.

Palate:Medium thick body.

Overall:This is a very solid stout, not extraordinary, but easy drinking and sessionable.

Bottle.  Pours black with thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt.  Taste of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt and light smokiness.  Thin mouthfeel.  Had this years ago and remembered it being better.  It was just OK.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.[ Courtesy of Secret Winter Santa ]. Clear dark brown color with a average, creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is light heavy malty, roasted, chocolate malt, wood, oak. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, coffee bitter, dark malt, roasted. Body is medium, texture is oily - creamy, carbonation is soft. [20110112]

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2011 This is from a 12oz bottle contract brewed by D L Geary sample 6/23/2008

Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights when held to the light. Fluffy mocha head that laces the class on the way down. The nose is deep chocolate and coffee, nice deep roasty maltiness. Some fig and dried cherries in there too. Taste is creamy, velvety, chocolaty goodness. Slight alcohol bite and a little ash in the middle. Leaves a bitter roasted coffee in the aftertaste. Thick body with a silky mouthfeel and a medium dry finish. Just an excellent brew. Ive had this several times and I just keep coming back for more.
Bottle shared by Dak.  Dark brown with a tan head. Roasty, ashy aroma with a hint of chocolate covered coffee beans. Toasted flavor with tobacco, charred wood and chocolate. Really nice brew.

Bottle at the Water Street Tavern.  Black with little head.  Not sure how old the bottle might have been.  Beginning is roasty with an hoppy and coffee end.  This is a very good stout, one of my favorites

Pours an opaque dark brown/black, with one finger foamy tan head. Smell is of milk chocolate, malty sweetness, coffee (which becomes dominant after warming), and a bit of dark fruit and smoke. Taste is similar; roasted malts, lighter coffee, chocolate, and a light bitterness prevail here. Medium bodied with soft carbonation; a bit syrupy but very, very smooth.

Pitch black with a small medium brown head.  Coffee, cocoa, medium roasted malts in the aroma.  Smooth, dry mouth and dryer finish.  Flavor is full of roasted malts, coffee notes, cocoa, light vanilla, toffee.  Has a real light bitterness from the roasted malts. A real nice stout that is a nice finish to 2010.

From notes:

12oz bottle:
Pours a deep dark brown, almost black with thick tan head that quickly fades leaving spots of lacing.

Slightly acrid roasted malt aroma with hints f oatmeal, chocolate, burnt toast and smoke.

Medium bodied with roster bitter chocolate malt flavor as well as some licorice, coffee, oatmeal, toffee and hazelnut. Slightly sweet but a bit too bitter with a dry finish.

22oz:
Pours pitch black and opaque with thick mocha colored hear that slowly fades leaving chunks of lacing behind.

Roasted malt aroma with silky sweet dark chocolate notes as well as hints of coffee bean, burnt toast, licorice and smoke.

Fuller bodied run the 12oz with a silkier chocolate malt presnce. Slightly more smokey with more of a bitter coffee bean flavor. It also has a subtle lactic creaminess that the 12oz lactic making it more complex and quaffable. Hits of licorice and hazelnut before a bitter dry finish. Better balanced than he smaller bottle.
Pretty thin for a stout. Great appearance and respectable aroma, but not pleased.  Easy drinking though.

Received as an extra in a trade with bmanning.

A: Pours black with a fairly-substantial brown head that eventually recedes into some decent lacing.

S: Lots of roasted coffee, malt, and chocolate. A few dark fruits make their way in alongside some faint hop presence, but the coffee/chocolate balance is what really makes this one shine.

T: Coffee and chocolate dominate again. The roasted characteristics of each blend together very well, creating the best-tasting American Stout that I have had the chance of having.

M: Quite creamy and smooth with moderate carbonation.

D: Very high. Fairly-low alcohol to complexity ratio, so this is definitely one I could sip all day.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-30-2009

Decent sized light brown head of fine bubbles.  Reduces rather quickly.  Nice roasty and chocolaty aroma with some raisins and malts.  Color is a very dark brown with a hint of red.  Mild coffee flavor with more roasted grains and carbon.  Pretty fleeting flavor that hits strong up front then fades away rather quickly.  Chocolate and some late bitterness.  Somewhat thin for a stout and not that heavy of a drink which is nice in a stout.  Lingering roastyness and a slight metallic aftertase.  A decent stout.
22 once thanks to  porterhouse. Pitch dark light head. Nice roast to it. Thin body. But a very good take on the dry stout. Enjoyable.

THOUGHTS: Nice, but not quite as good as I would have thought from all the high ratings. A little one sided, but it was a nice side. I was surprised at a dry stout having this high of an ABV, but it was definitely a dry as opposed to a sweet stout. It had a nice, balanced flavor.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown with red highlights, but appeared nearly, opaque black at wider points in the glass. It also had an average to large, creamy, tan, head that mostly diminished, but kept a nice blanket and left fair lacing. The aroma had heavy roasted malt and bitter coffee; lighter burnt malt; hints of dark chocolate; light earthy hops; slight chocolate, but mostly it was coffee. THe initial flavor was light to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, slightly sour and lightly bitter; while the finish was sweet and bitter; There was coffee, hints of chocolate, then cold hot cocoa, then sweet coffee, followed by bitter coffee, a little sour coffee, too, near the bottom of the bottle. Also, some roasted malt and burnt toast. The medium to full body was slick and silky ( and went down very easily) had soft carbonation and and ever so slightly metallic finish.

Bottle via a trade with a best before of 12/10. Pours with a deep brown, near black body with a lasting dark tan head.  Decent lace. Aromas of cocoa powder, leather, currants, flint, smoke, campfire, and dark berries. Flavors of chocolate, leather, smoke, almonds, tobacco and a light dark-fruit note. Lively bubbles. Well done, very pleasant to drink.
Dark brown, basically black, thick frothy light tan foam.  Aroma is very dry, calcium, hard water, roasty.  Taste is fuller roast, dry, some chocolate, just too much of a calcium taste for me.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2013 12oz bottle courtesy of Rob+Karen.  Brown-black with some stained glass red edges.  Not much of a head, this and oily beige.  Sweet but mellow caramel chocolate aroma.  My previous rating had stated this was a straightforward session Stout, but take that as testament to its drinkability.  Big, roasty, full bodied.,,but retains an excellent balance.

Bottle. Black pour, thin brownish head, quickly recedes into a ring with a bit of lacing on the glass. Aroma is chocolaty, some burnt toast, kind of light aroma (or heavy if comparing with Guinness Draught). Taste is the high point of this beer, taste of fresh bread (some toastiness) with a very well balanced sweetness - chocolaty/molasses. A hint of dry herbs (anise) to finish it off dry. Palate is very sessionnable, well dosed carbonation, medium-light bodied. Damn Id love to have this on tap at my local bar.

I had been trying to locate this beer for some time without luck, but I finally found it in Bar Harbor.  While it didnt quite live up to my expectations, it is still a very tasty beer.  The beer pours a dark brown but looks relatively thin compared to many stouts and has no head to speak of.  THe beer has a nice aroma of hops, malt, pine and prune.  This beer has a bit of a coffee flavor with chocolate and is somewhat creamy.  However, the flavors didnt quite form the unified taste I was looking for, so the beer was a bit rougher to drink that I would have liked (this beer is better with food).  The beer is relatively smooth in the mouth and has very small bubbles.

Pours a dark brown color with a creamed coffee-colored head. Roasted coffee in the nose with chocolate syrup and graham. Roasty flavor up front with more syrup and a smokey aftertaste. Light bitterness. Easy to drink, a little watery and short in the finish.

Bomber from Oak Tree. Pours very black with a 1 finger foamy tan head. Aromas of smooth burnt malt, coffee and chocolate. Full bodied; foamy carbonation. Flavor is chocolate, burnt malt and either hop bitter or something bitter from the malt. Very flavorful. Having this after some 14.5% BA and this stands up. Its good. Having pizza in a bit!!!
22 oz. bomber thanks to jwattsrugger.  a pitch black with little tanish head.  more complex than i actually thought it would be.  molasses and hoppy notes.  very well done.

Bomber thanks to photomike.   Pretty much black pour with a small tan head.   Smokey chocolate and dried fruit aroma.   The flavor is lightly sweet and smokey with some fruit, light cardboard, and some acidic roast.   The palalte is a little chalky but decently robust.   Not bad, but certainly not exceptional as I had been lead to believe.

Poured from bomber, dark brown with small tan head that quickly dissipated.  Nose of spicy chocolate, taste was on the sweet side, not too dry for a dry stout, flavors of chocolate and coffee. Full bodied beer with a nice long finish.

A solid pour into my 25cl tulip glass produces a two-finger thick, lightly browned, dark tan colored head.  The beer is a deep, concentrated brown color that approaches black.  When held up directly to the light it shows flashes of a brilliantly clear, ruby hue.  The aroma smells of richly roasted, slight acidic grain, burnt / toasted grain husks, a berry like fruitiness that is quite apparent if you dig around a bit, roasted toast and perhaps a touch of smokiness.  Somehow the nose makes this beer seem quite light as the nose is quite a bit more washed out than I would expect from a stout.  The dominant roast character seems to be missing the malty richness that is needed to carry the dominant roast character.

Somewhat thicker feeling than the aroma would have suggested, this is actually fairly viscous and has a heft to it that is nice; to be honest though it only seems so because the nose made this seem so thin.  Sweet, dark malt richness adds flavors of chocolate that help to tame the roast character of the nose.  The finish is fairly dry with a bitter, roasted malt note, but there is also a soft bitter hop bit that is noticeable from the finish too end.   Flavors of roasted coffee, a touch of smoky burnt character and some acidic burnt grain notes round out the notes found here.

While the flavor is a lot better than the nose led me to be, I find that I am quite disappointed.  I was really expecting a lot from this beer and it just sort of fizzles out; it is nice and easy drinking, but isnt nearly as flavorful as I was hoping.  I will happily stick to my go-to Kalamazoo Stout from Bells.

Bar Harbor Cadillac Mtn. Stout (bottle)
A: snifter. Obsidian in color. Creamed coffee colored head. Good retention and really nice lacing.

S: sweet raisins, plums, chocolate, and some coffee, hints of black cherries.

T: nice big hoppy stout. Some coffee and cocoa form the roasted malts, big roasted flavors. Some plums, figs, and dark berries. Hints of tobacco.

M: full bodied and very thick. Nice dry feel from the hops. Good carbonation level.

D: great dry stout and well worth getting because it is phenomenal. I see why it won a Platinum Medal.

355ml bottle. Deep brown with tan head that lingers nicely and leaves a little lace. Nose is heavy on pure roasted malt and a little coffee/dark chocolate underneath with some strange notes of stone or mineral. More of the same in the mouth with an odd off beat and it falls a little flat.

good head nice colour. big stout notes. nice coffee and roasted malts. there is a gamey/iron rich undertone to this that kinda reminds me of clamato juice. nice creamy notes on the palate. coffee and roasted malts. good body but im not blown away by this one. a good session beer.

bottle thanks to JTClockwork at the Tally tasting, pours thick black with a medium brown head.  Aroma is cocoa and roasted malts.  Flavor is dry throughout with roasted malts, some nutty character and a solid hop finish that dries things out well.  I like it.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2010 Courtesy of Smokepot23
Bottle:  The aroma consists of lots of chocolate, caramel, vanilla, black licorice, light roasted malt, and a touch of alcohol.  It pours dark brown with no transparency and a small beige head.  The flavor starts with dark chocolate and caramel.  Theres finish has light-moderate roasted malt and a hint of black licorice and coffee.  Medium bodied with mild carbonation.
(12oz bottle via trade with BA abuliarose) clearish dark brown, very few tan bubbles. Nose of dry cocoa, sweet dark chocolate, wheaty grain, and bitter chocolate. Watery bitter chocolate finish.
Smells like coffee and burnt toast. Caramel. It is burning the back of my throat.
Bottle thanks to thirdeye11.  Black pour with a cream head.  Nose is dried malts, chocolate, and roasted malts.  Nice on the palate, flavor is roasted malts, chocolate, and very dry.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2011 bottle at dakines on 6/6/10.

clear woody dark brown colored pour with a small tan head.

it smells like wet wood, earth, yeast, coffee and roast... but mostly wet wood.

the flavor is similar... stinky old coffee, wet wood, moist earth, grass and an acidic coffee finish. theres a tingling sensation on the palate in between. 

its a bit on the thin side but quite drinkable... 6/3/6/3/13/3.1
bottle 3/21/11.

im picking up notes of fresh on the vine tomatoes, peppers and mild choco. the palate feels a little flat in the middle. 6/3/6/3/13

Pours black with quickly dissipating medium brown head. Unbelievably rich aroma of roast and some coffee. Carbonation is medium, though maybe higher than Id like for the style. The flavor brings loads of bacon and roast with a dry finish. Man the aroma is great, but I just cant past the pork in this brew.

12oz bottle from Secret Santa(RCL). Pours near black with dark tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, and some coffee. Flavors of roasted malts, sweet chocolate, light coffee, and some dark fruit. Finishes dry with dark fruit. Pretty tasty stout.
12 oz bottle.  Pours black with one inch tan head.  Very tasty with roasty malts and almost a little coffee.  Thus one is a tad sweet but it is balanced with a slight but lingering bitterness.

Bottle Tally Tasting 10 Coal black ale with a small, creamy, khaki head. The nose is very nice; the standouts are the standards  dark chocolate and restrained black coffee. Full-bodied with medium carbonation. The flavor is acrid, acidic and moderately bitter. Finishes singed, tangy and a touch carbonaceous. Bottle courtesy of jtclockwork!

Great for Maine, but certainly overrated.  Pours a light roasted brown color with a trim beige head.  Smells of funk and lactose.  Tastes of each with a note of wet wood and malt.  Possibly infected, but I think this is just lacking depth and sweetness.  Meh.
From a bottle poured a dark brown color with a small amount of head.  Strong coffee chocolate malty flavor with a lingering finish.
Thanks to sideshow for this one.  Dark brown, tan head.  Roasty, ashy aroma with a hint of chocolate covered coffee beans.  Toasted flavor with tobacco, charred wood and chocolate. Nice stuff.

Poured from a bottle with a best enjoy date by 12/09. Seeing as it is 12/09, I think it is time to enjoy this one! Bottle says it is a Platinum Medal World Champ Dry Stout. 
Pours a deep, dark brown/black color with a 1/2 inch head that slowly recedes. 
Smells of dark roast, chocolate, and slight coffee. First sips yields a nice flavor of dark roast with a slight maybe cherry flavor. A surpisingly light mouthfeel. Minimal lacing. Finishes fairly cleanly.

Dark brown, black pour.  dark beige head... Aroma is manure, dark chocolate, some dark fruit, raisin, date, chocolate dust.  
Flavor is  Flavor is extreme cream with dark chocolate and manure chocolatiness, super poopiness. which is good.  YUM

Courtesy of james. The pour is quite black with a nice one finger beige head. The aroma is loaded with lacitc roast, farm animal dungy poo, roast, and epic peat. Lots of loam and peat literally fill the room. The flavor is lactic earth and creamy shit. Tons of fecal notes that are oddly well placed. Creamy chocolate and coffee follow. Mmmmm. The palate is rich, thick, and creamy with a silken mouthfeel and roasty finish. World class.
Proud to have this as my go-to stout.  I buy it by the case at Tullys in Wells.

Bomber shared by BOLTZ7555.  Thanks Jason  Ive wanted to try this one for awhile!  Pours deep dark brown with a half finger beige head.  The nose is ashy cocoa, roasted malt and mild coffee.  The taste is ash, burnt malt, chocolate and coffee grounds.  Medium mouthfeel  lighter than anticipated.  Mellow sessionable stout.
UPDATED: MAY 30, 2010 Pour black with little tan head. Nose is roasted malts and bakers chocolate. Taste is the same with some smoke. Very dry stout.

22oz bottle:

Pours an opaque black ale with a large sticky brown cap. Aroma is complex: Cocoa,coffee, figs, metal, charred husk, light sweetness and fusel alcohol.

Rich silky mouth feel, Big flavors in front feature the roasty-coffee-cocoa-fig profile, midway this develops more complexity. Long viscous finish with a charred-metallic bite at the end.

World class big stout. The key here is complexity....sip slowly and enjoy.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with and courtesy of Vinny. Pours a pitch black opaque with a thin, slightly lacy beige head. Aroma of cocoa nibs, cream, milk, roast, esspresso beans, and hints of toasted almonds. Full bodied with an insanely rich, velvety palate. Finishes with a lovely bit of warming in the belly. Great dry stout.

Appearance: Dark brown with an off white to beige 1 finger crown. Some retention and lacing decorate the drinking vessel.

Smell: Loads of character here. I smell wood notes, light bourbon notes, roast malt, a touch of licorice.

Taste: same as nose....delicious!

Mouthfeel: Way thin.

Drinkability: Delicious flavor and thin body makes this an easy drinker.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-29-2009

Bottle.  Pours black with a tan head.  Lots of roasted malt, chocolate, and dark coffee in the nose - great stuff.  Medium-bodied, full of flavor.  Roasty malt, chocolate, balanced perfectly with the bitterness.  Finishes with more chocolate, coffee, nice bitterness. Great stout.

Thanks for the bottle rgtravers! it pours brown with a thin, disappearing tan head. The aroma has chocolate, coffee, and oatmeal with good quality roasted malts. The flavor is oatmeal, coffee and a very roasted, bitter, ashy finish. This is very dry and balanced. A very well executed stout.
12oz bottle. Dark black pour with a creamy tan head. Thinner than expected but still very tasty. Tastes of chocolate and licorice. Nice dry finish. Very well crafted stout.

12oz bottle given to my by mdfb79.  Thanks Red!  Pours a totally opaque black with a thin, slightly creamy, slightly clumpy beige head.  The aroma is excellent and damn near perfect for the style: toasted bread, crackers, biscuit, brown sugar, a little licorice, and malts.  No coffee aroma, which is actually a little nice.  Flavor is also spot on, toasted brown bread, sweet malts, a little molasses, brown sugar, crackers, sugary without being too sweet.  Full bodied without being thick.  Extremely drinkable.  Finish is lightly sweet and a little dry.  This is a perfectly executed dry stout.  This doesnt need one single addition of any ingredient.

Bottle acquired via trade with sigma23...THANKS TIM!!!  Dark mahogany pour produced a creamy latte head that left a clump or two of lacing.  Aroma is cocoa, toasted malt, and roasted coffee beans.  Flavorful but not robust, this one shows chocolate, caramel, and toffee.  Although it looked a bit thin in the pour, it seemed to thicken on the palate.  Not creamy but present.  Good brew.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is dark cola with 2 fingers of quickly dissipating tan foam on top.  Nose is coffee beans, roasted malt, and lactose.  Taste is light coffee and roasted malt.  The body is relatively thin and the finish is dry on this beer.  Because of this, I think this would be a great dinner beer.  I enjoyed this and would drink again!

From a trade courtesy of "The Wheelman" in Maine, this poured a dark brown color with a robust tan head and some decent lacing. The nose is primarily of roasted malts with additional aromas of coffee, chocolate, and ripe fruit.  The body is medium to heavy with a good creamy mouthfeel. The flavor is strong with the roasted malt character and there is some bitterness.   The finish is bitter.  Overall  this is a very nice dry stout..

Bottle at the Rosso release at Captain Lawrence.  Pours a murky brown with a thin beige head.  Caramel and sweet chocolate on the nose.  Flavors follow the nose with a sweet caramel chocolate to it, albeit a bit thin on the body.  Roast and cocoa on the finish.  Just ok.

Got this in a trade with CrellMoset. Thanks for the opportunity to try this great beer!

A- Very dark red/brown body that pours with a nice creme brulee colored foamy cap. Head fades pretty quickly to a thick collar and traces of lacing are left all the way down the glass. When held up to the light glimmering red hues shine through.

S-Rich, dark chocolate malt, a faint toffee sweetness, and a touch of roasted malt. Smells robust.

T-Taste is much like the smell. Rich dark chocolate malt upfront with a hint of toffee sweetness and just a touch of toastiness. The finish is all dark chocolate flavor which fades slowly. What is left behind is just a touch of roastedness, chocolate, and toffee.

P-Medium carbonation, and a wonderful smooth and creamy, yet full mouthfeel.

O- I know that this description sounds just like any other stout but the balance here is immaculate. The chocolate is the main character but the toffee and the roasted flavors play wonderful supporting roles. Nothing is overpowering and it all goes down wonderful and smooth...If this were a car it would ride like a Cadillac.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-21-2008 01:20:26

22 oz bottle from Canals Hainesport. Pours a slightly liquidy deep dark blackish brown body sittin underneath a bubbly beige head. Aroma is nice with lots of complexity, earth, hops, chocolate, coffee, soy sauce, tobacco, leather, even a touch of cola. The body is actually thicker then the appearance lets on with a medium to full body, a creamy full muthfeel and a chalky finish. Flavor of licorice, anise, coffee grounds, uncooked chocolate cake batter, grassy hops. Wow much better then I was expecting.....sort of like Wierd Scence, thought it would be watchable bt it turned out to be a timeless classic.

Coffee brown pour with a tan head that quickly fades.  Nose is roasted malt, light coffee, with a tiny bit of chocolate.  Flavor is the same and adds a hint of char in the semi-dry finish.  I found it a little bit lacking in mouthfeel.  It was actually quite thin/watery (even for a simple dry stout), and I thought that just a tad more heft in the body would really carry the wonderful flavors and aromas a little better.  All nitpicking aside ... this is a straightforward, easy drinking, solid, flavorful stout.  I am glad to have finally been able to try it, but I wonder if it has changed over the years(?).

First impression was incredibly smooth. Starts off with a beautiful black pour with a small tan head. Aroma is roast malt, chocolate, coffee. Flavor is similar but not sweet. Quite dry and bitter. Finishes dry with a very nice lasting after taste.

nice surprisingly good dry stout here folks! goes down really quick, just like water. nice and balanced, this isnt unpleasant in any way. nice and roasty, sweet, dry, oily, perfect session stout. def a return to great session stuff.

A: The pour is a dark brown color with a thin tan head and some noticeable carbonation.

S: The aroma is primarily of roasted malt with some nice notes of coffee, chocolate, and perhaps even some charcoal.

T: The roasted character really comes through in the flavor as well, along with some more coffee and a slight bitterness.

M: The body is medium with a moderate to high level of carbonation and a slightly dry finish.

D: This was a nice beer and one that Ive wanted to try for quite some time. Im lucky to have some more sitting at home.

Bottle via trade thanks to kmurray8621 on BA.  Pours black or very dark brown with a very large, lasting foamy tan head.

Aroma really jumps out at you with sharp roast and bitter coffee.  Some chocolate notes.

Flavor is really awesome and full.  Sweet caramel malt, dark fruits, bitter chocolate, coffee, and roast all in there.  Pretty complex.

Medium-full body with an extremely smooth and creamy mouthfeel.

Not really as dry as your typical dry stout, and way more flavorful than just about anything in the style.  Overall really amazing stuff.  Very drinkable and very awesome
Aroma is quite dark roasted malts with a hint of burning plastic/electrical fire.  Super velvety mouthfeel.   Nice dry, yet rich flavor.  Really nice.  Straightforward but superbly crafted stout.

Pours dark brown with a khaki head. The aroma is lots of chocolate and coffee. The flavor is coffee with a hint of smoke. You also get some roasted malt. The beer finishes very dry. Thick, creamy mouthfeel and low carbonation.

Bottle from BelgianBeerGal...thanks Amy! - Pours deep and dark with a huge frothy tan head. Smells of coffee, raisins, bourbon, toffee, chocolate, and a tiny bit of heat in the end. Really rich, sweet, and smooth--just like it like it. Taste is wonderfully smooth, with dark malt, coffee, chocolate, lactose, and a touch of smoke on the finish. The carbonation is just right, and the body is fairly light, but nowhere near watery. Stupendous.

Wow.  For a dry stout, this beer was outstanding.  Pours stout brown with a khaki head.  Nose is cocoa, licorice, earth, and coffee.  Flavor is cocoa, coffee, black licorice, and some dark fruit.  Lingering roast in this medium to full-bodied beer.  Very nice.

Guess what color this one was? Just kidding, it is obviously black. The head was foamy, tan, and sizable. The aroma was roasted, charred, and dark chocolates. the flavor made me think "This is what Guinness should be". The label did not lie, the chocolate flavor was "focused". This was good stuff but 12oz would have been enough.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-21-2007 22:14:17

courtesy of markwise
pours brown, off-white head
aroma, roasted, coffee malts, hints of mocha and chocolate.
flavor, smooth and silky palate, plenty of dark malts, coffee roast, chocolate nibs, finishes with a very mild touch of bitterness.
Easy drinker, load of good malty flavors. While the aroma is a bit on the weak side, the flavor makes up for it with a quaff of malt goodness.
Thanks to BelgianBeerGal. Bottle # 21. Flavor consists of soy sauce and chocolate and almost a woodiness to it. Quite delicious

bottle sent as a bonus from sigma23.  poured dark brown/black with a beige head.  aroma was roasted grain, caramel, and coffee.  flavor was grains, coffee bitter, alcohol, and baking cocoa.  light-medium body with medium carbonation.

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours a deep, dark brown with tan head. Aroma of nice dark roasted grain, malt, some nice hop aromas. Flavor is dark roasted grain, baking chocolate, very faint hop flavor, nice dark roasted bitter. Mouth feel is medium body with medium carbonation. Overall, not bad at all!
Pours black with a small wispy white head. Aromas of olives, dark chocolates,and a hint of coffee. Medium bodied for a stout. Best part is enjoying it with great friends!!

Sampled from 22-oz bomber during Darkness Day 2009 in Brooklyn Center, MN. Pours an opaque dark brown colored brew with a thick tan head that slowly dissipates. Aroma of toasted dark malt, chocolate, light coffee and floral hops. Taste is quite smooth, medium bodied, flavors of dark chocolate, toasted dark malt, a hint of whole milk and some burnt bread. Finish is semi-dry with a burnt toast and chocolate aftertaste.

Mild, but thick, beige head. No light passes through even at the edges. The color is nearly black.

Black patent malt presence with a soured milk aroma.

Here is a dry stout. Tastes very close to the traditional Guiness. Unlike the smell, there is no hint of milk to the beer. Very bitter from the black patent malt (and, perhaps, roasted unmalted barley). Burnt toast flavors. The only detraction is thinner body and high level of carbonation. Great aftertaste of black coffee and burnt sugar (still not sweet).

Bottle thanks to BanditBrewingCo(BA)! Black with a long-lived cream head. Nose of strong, creamy malt, slight mint, and minor alcohol. Flavor has a ton of malt, light hop balance, some chocolate. Very balanced throughout with a nice, strong, robust malt finish. Very enjoyable stuff.
Roasty, burnt, yet light and airy with lingering bitterness, no fruitiness, very easy drinking, maybe too easy, this is what a dry stout should be

22oz.  Totally black, head is the color of a latte.  Aroma is dark roasted barley, maybe some chocolate malt.  Very low carbonation.  Medium body.  Finish is pretty dark (not as dark as the aroma) and lasts a very long time.  Very little hop character, a tickle in the front and an inkling in the finish.  Yay beer!

On tap at the brewery. A dark ale with an aroma of coffee and bitter hops. Its easy to drink and tastey, but unfortunately the bar had been set increasingly high for this style and its tough to compare to some of the stronger American breweries.

A: From a 22 oz bottle. Poured with an average-sized, fizzy, tan head that eventually dissipated to a thin layer. Body is jet-black and completely opaque as a result.

S: Mmmm... heavy malt aroma with lots of coffee and bitter, dark chocolate. Quite earthy.

T: Wow, this is a flavorful stout! A very strong coffee and chocolate taste at the beginning. Finishes off slightly bitter. Flavor stays with you for a nice, long time as you continue to sip and enjoy.

M: Great on the palate: full-bodied and a creamy texture, with soft carbonation. Smooth... very smooth.

D: Pretty much lives up to its reputation... Bar Harbor Brewing Co. should take more pride in this beer than they seem to do. At their brew store in Bar Harbor, ME, they have posters up claiming it to be "... the beer that beat Guinness!" in a taste test. Big deal. I informed the beer pouring girl there that it was in the top 100 rated beers on BA... she had no idea it did that well. Time to start bragging more!
Pours black with medium brown head. Not much aroma, but a bit of chocolate. Full bodied. Flavor is chocolate, graham cracker, and coffee. The alcohol is completely hidden. Really good stout.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2010 Like most stouts from a bottle there was no great apperance here. However the taste is what wins this beer marks. Had a roasted coffee, chocolate taste. One of the nicer bottled stouts on the market from an excellent local brewery.

Beer gets low marks for appearance, what was there of the head only appeared after some agitation, black liquid with ruby highlights, not much in the way of lace.

Smell is heavy malt, toffee, chocolate, a small hint of concentrated vanilla. No sign of alcohol or roasted malt. 

Taste is altogether another story, quite good and difficult to explain. Tobacco, chocolate is very light, kind of creamy on the mouth. Thick, but bubbly.

I could chalk up the appearance to the pour, which I thought was good enough, but maybe an outside factor is influencing this, because other than that, this is a world class brew.
22 ounce bottle in tulip.  Black with tan flat head.  Coffee ice cream aroma.  Coffee chocolate raisin with very dry finish.  Nice soft mouthfeel and low carbo.  Very good.
Pour out of bottle into glass. Looks and smells great. Doesnt taste like it smells, much milder, almost watered down. Easy to drink, slightly chocolate bitter finish. Too watery for a stout for me.
22oz bottle. Poured a dark brown color with a larger sized off white head. Aromas were roasty, toasty some caramel, and earthy. Tastes of roast, lighter caramel, the same earthiness, and chocolate.
Another old rating, gf brought this back from maine for me. Solid roastiness and pretty tastey but a little thin on the body.
Black in color with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee.  Coffee taste with dark chocolate and roasted malts.  Dry finish.  Very nice beer!

Bottle from a trade with Dickinsonbeer.  Thanks Paul!  This guy is super solid.  When warm, a nice grainy coffee chocolate darkness, like a Foreign (watch out though since cold on this beer makes it smell like copper).  Flavor is much the same with dark chocolate, ashy coffee.  Very nice rocky texture and finish.
Nice deep color with a chocolate head. Had this with a nice slice of firebaked pizza.
Thanks to KP for this beer (I think). Dark black with brown head. Nose of roasted malts, chocolate, cocoa and earth. Flavor is similar, but more bitter than expected. Nice dry finish.
This was a good solid stout. Nice dark pour with roasty aroma with some chocolate. Taste is sweet and smoot with a nice bitter roast to balance it out.
From bottle. Great black colour with a tan head. Liquorice aroma with roasted malt. Bitter flavour at first, then settles to a smooth warm liquorice flavour.

The aroma was pretty much all chocolate and roasted malts, perhaps a hint of earth too. Black pour with a meringue like tan head that sat all the way to the finish. A great looking beer. Looks like it was pulled from a cask actually. Flavors of chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, and a touch of dark fruit. Nice underlying sweetness, and a clean lightly hopped finish. Really tasty and well done.

Bottle, shared w. Tim & Jacob.  Thanks Tim!  Black, tan head.  Nose is rich roasted malt, very dark toffee, some tar & very dark fruits.  Flavor is caramel, milk, toffee, really nice dark roasted malts.  Long caramel finish w. nice roast.  Really good!
Very dark brown in color with ruby highlights and a good sized tan head. Aroma is of coffee and dark fruit. Flavor is of prune, raisins, coffee, and dark chocolate.

Thanks to Kevlar for this one!

22oz brown glass crown cap. No dating, but a lot of sediment at the bottom.

Appearance: Poured into a British Imperial Pint glass. Thick, tan sudsy head three fingers high settles down after a minute to half-inch. Black and opaque, a very tiny little brownish red shows at the edge when held up to a light bulb.

Nose: Dried grains, dried figs and apricots, medium roast ground coffee, bakers chocolate, dry newspaper (not faulted).

Palate: Medium bodied. Elegant on the palate. Light notes of cold-processed chocolate, light roast black coffee, oats, and a splash of cream (without the creamy texture, though).

Notes: A really drinkable and balanced stout. I was surprised at how light it was on the palate given the color and the nose, but that only makes it more drinkable. Alcohol is in balance, too. I can understand why this beer is often asked for here in Vermont. Tasty.
Very well done.  Brown pour with a tan head.  Coffee and chocolate in the aroma.  Nice balance between the chocolate and the coffee in the taste.  Thinner body and a dry finish.

bomber thanks to mcox90.  I had been wanting one of these for awhile.  Pours dark brown with a nice tan head.  Nose is of chocolate and became smoky as it warmed up.  Taste was of chocolate and roast malt.  Mouthfeel was medium and dry with a slight bitterness.  Very nice.

Bomber shared by theisti at a Chiefs tailgate. Pours a deep opaque brown with a creamy light tan head. Milk chocolate, roasted malt and a lactose note are on the nose. It does not smell like a dry stout. Light to medium-bodied and creamy with soft carbonation. The flavor is of chocolaty, dry, roasted malt. Pretty nice. Thanks for sharing this with us, Tim.
Medium brown/ruby red pour with tan head and lace. Medium roasted malt that hints of chocolate. Light to medium hop  bitter. Large coffee and roasted malt. Medium bodied a tad thin. Very nice beer.

This poured dark brown/black in color with a moderate light brown head.  This had quite nice aromas of chocolate, rich coffee, sweet caramel and vanilla.  In the mouth this was medium-bodied and started off powerful then faded to a dry/bitter finish.  The midpalate lacked concentration and flavor though this should have been expected given the alcohol level.
esta la compre en portland maine y me la tome en sibar.  es una buena stout, un poco menos caramelo y mas hop y esto la hace mas tipo dark ale, mi tipo

Brown bottle, 12 ounces, gift from Steve Gamble received on September 13 2008, savoured on November 20 2008; eye: black, opaque, beige head that turns into a tiny ring, slight lacing; nose: roasting, vanilla, dark chocolate, light burnt, light acridness, basement; mouth: roasting, light acridness, vanilla, feels more the important presence of the hops that its taste, dry finale in roasted malt with a good presence of vanilla, oily texture, slight astringency, lactic, mildly bitter, medium-full body, average carboantion; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 12 onces, cadeau de Steve Gamble reçu le 13 septembre 2008, savourée le 20 novembre 2008; il : noire, opaque, mousse beige qui se transforme en un petit anneau, très légère dentelle; nez : torréfaction, vanille, chocolat noir, léger brûlé, légère âcreté, cave; bouche : torréfaction, légère âcreté, vanille, on sent plus l’importante présence du houblon qu’on la goûte, finale sèche en malt torréfié avec une bonne présence de vanille, texture huileuse, très légère astringence, lactique, moyennement amère, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation moyenne; en résumé : très bonne

22 oz bottle courtesy of mcox90. Pour is brown black ruby with a tan nose. Aroma of milk chocolate, dusty dry roast and leafy tobacco.  Taste is sweet malt, roast and the lactic milkiness. Interesting, smooth and well made. Thanks for sending this my way, Michael.
everything from Bar Harbor Brewing Company is great.  Brewery tours available too.

Thanks to Ross for sharing this one.
Pours black with a firm tan head.
Aroma of roast malt, some chocolate and a touch of coffee.
Smooth palate that delivers a slightly sweet, roasty flavor.
Very decent for it’s age and alcohol content.

I did a side by side tasting of this beer.  The new mass produced 12 oz version and the 22 oz hand crafted version.  I rated the 22 oz version.  The version that made this stout popular.

12 oz
Bottle pours pitch black with tan head.  Has 1 dimensional aroma featuring a slight malt base.  Has a medium light body.  Its a bit thin for a stout.  Flavor is somewhat hoppy and has malt flavor that is somewhat boring.  Overall this version is just an ok brew.  Not much to talk about really.  This version would get a rating no more than a 3.1 or 3.2

22 oz
Bottle pours pitch black with thick tan head.  Has a wonderful aroma of sweet roasted malts and chocolate.  Very complex.  Has a medium body and is much fuller compared to the 12 oz version.  Flavor is smooth and roasty.  Dark malts, chocolate, caramel, coffee, toffee, and just tasty goodness.  Overall, this is one of the best dry stouts Ive tried.  Im glad I got to taste the mass produced version and the version that made this such a popular stout.  Its truely world class.

Bottle. Pours black with a nice two finger tan head that left good lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and light coffee. Flavor was smooth with dark roasted malts, dark chocolate, mild coffee and a hint of dark fruit with a medium body and a light bitterness.  Excellent dry stout.

03 Bottle shared by Ross. Poured black with a tan head that left good lacing. Head settles but renews with a twirl of the glass. Aroma of chocolate, molasses and a slight roast. The flavor had the same chocolate and molasses come out with a mix of coffee, more pronounced roast and hints of hops. Medium body with a slightly fizzy carbonation. Still very decent for it’s age.

Bottle - Poured a very dark black/brown in color with a thin dark tan head that faded quickly. Aroma is slightly sweet and fruity with a strong character of coffee, dark roasted malts and a hint of chocolate.  Thinner than I expected. A good stout, but not one of the best

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2009 Newer 22oz bottle conditioned version. Yes I heard all the hype leading up to this tasting, but it definitely delivered. People always comment this beats Guiness!  Not even close, this makes Guiness taste like tepid, watered down coffee.  Just phenomenal.

12oz Geary brewed bottle.  I’ve seen lots of hype for this stuff over the years and have been craving a good stout for a few weeks now... this rating may be biased, I’m trying my damndest not to believe the hype, not necessarily trying to trash it, but trying not to love it because all the cool kids do.  Anyway, yeah, it’s black, it’s a stout.  Tan foam that fades down to a thin ring.  Mildly oily nose with some roasted notes.  Flavor is just damn nice, some mild herbal hoppiness buried underneath the spot on malts.  Perfect palate for the flavor, not quite sure how else to describe that.

2003 bottle courtesy of Ross. We thought this one would be a oxidation bomb, and this is surprisingly still good. Pours a deep brown with some reddish hues, and a beige head. Aroma is not very inviting, sort of like wet cardboard. Medium bodied with a slightly thin texture. Flavor of cocoa, nuts, and dark roasted malts. The hops have faded, bringing forth more sweetness on the palate. This is actually still drinkable and decent, even though it probably tastes totally different fresh.
Oxidationfest Tasting at illinsmittys curtesy of ross.  "It’s better than ass!"  ’03-’04.  Extremely Dark brown, wth light brown head.  Nose of sweet cocoa and malt.  Medium Thin body.  Impressive.

Bottle. [thank you, asheft] Pours almost completely black with brown edges. On top sits a great, creamy, brown-beige, frothy head. Great aroma, sweet malts, chocolate, milk, toffee and light coffee. Medium carbonation, lighish mouthfeel. Flavour is nicely sweet, lots of chocolate and soft coffee. Pleasant long, roasted aftertaste with some hoppiness. Nice.

22 oz. bottle - pours thin, dark brown with foamy tan head, which fades quickly to the edges; roasty, nutty aromas; chocolate is very muted; light bodied, but very flavorful; crisp and smooth; decent, but a little on the light side

Bottle:  Dark brown with a huge, fluffy tan head.  Mostly coffee and chocolate up front with some light bitterness.  Roasty.  Tastes heavy with roast into mellow chocolate and a little bittersweetness in the trailer.  Some underlying coffee flavors.  Smooth, well balanced, and flavorful.  I forgot who sent this over the winter months, but cheers to them for this treat!

12oz Bottle pours black with a small caramel color head. Aroma is semi sweet, coffee, and dark dried fruits. Taste of coffee and bitter dark chocolate and malts with dark fruit undertones. Will re-rate based on the future bomber tasting.

Bottle - Poured a very dark black/brown in color with a thin dark tan head that faded quickly.  Aroma is slightly sweet and fruity with a strong character of coffee, dark roasted malts and a hint of chocolate.  Flavor is strong of coffee/espresso with chocolate and hints of dark fruits.  Slightly over carbonated.  Thinner than I expected.  Finish is bitter and lingering.  A good stout, but not one of the best

A side by side blind tasting of the 22oz bottles brewed at the original estate brewery vs. the 12oz version contract brewed at Gearys.

22oz:
Dark brown, with a creamy, dense head of beige that lasts throughout the glass wtih some decent lacework.

Aromatics filled with dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malts and plenty of caramel. A slight fruit note follows through and the nose finishes with a mildly sweet note.

The mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. Velvety and luscious.

Nougat, dark chocolate, mild espresso, and caramel lead off the pallet. Fudgy and a bit chewy. Mildly sweet with some dark fruit way underneath.

Finishes with lingering chocolate, roast, and nougat. 

Incredible smooth and drinkable. Somewhat rich and very balanced.

12oz:

Pours dark brown, identical in color to the bomber, but the head pours shorter and quickly dissapates. Barely a trace of lacework.

Aromatics are a blend of bitter chocolate, caramel, brownie bits, acrid malt and butterscotch. The nose is much drier, coarser, and slightly minerally, as well as hugely overun by the Ringwood yeast.

The mouthfeel is crisper, dryer, and slightly spritzy. Missing the smooth, velvet feel of the bomber.

Dark roasted malts, bitter chocolate, caramel, and roast coffee lead off the pallet.
Quite dry and slightly acrid. Butterscotch steps forward and detracts from the drinkability.

Finishes with some coarsesness, quite dry and roasty.

The two versions side by side have many glaring differences. The smooth, slightly sweet, and rounded sophistication of the original version is gone, and in place is the buttery Ringwood yeast, coarser carbonation, and dryer character.
The rating I’m giving this one is on the original version, with hopes that the new version being brewed at the brewpub will be up to grade.

22oz bottle, purchased at the brewery. Labeled "brew 15". Poured very deep brown, capped with a small brown head. Rich espresso aroma, with dark chocolate , some caramel malt, and mild herbal notes. Flavor of dark chocolate cocoa, and caramel, with some espresso bitterness. Silky smooth mouthfeel. Long roasted chocolate malt finish. Nice Stout. I had some of this atop Cadillac Mountain while watching the sunrise - it made a nice substitute for morning coffee.
My ace in the hole as far as Bar Harbor Brewing Company goes.  This beer didn’t beat all the other stouts due to luck.  I bought three cases of this and they were gone before I knew it.
user_location: New York City, New York, USA

text: @Richmond/Williamsburg Gathering-22 oz bottle-pours a light tan ring for a head and black with brown color.  Aroma is a bit mild dark malt-dry chocolate, dark fruit-raisin/plum.  Taste is soft dark malt-dry chocolate, dark fruit-raisin/plum, slight bite.  A bit thin on finish.  Thanks Immy for sharing.

Bottle and draught @ brewery.  Bllack pour with a faint coffee nose.  Nice hybrid sweet and imperial stout.   Nice well crafted miedieum badied stout that it easily drinkable.  Earthy flavor come sout better in the bottle conditioned version.

Richmond Summer Gathering. Black with a light brown head. Choco-coffee nose and flavor. Medium body. We sampled this right after the Pisgah Vortex II, and, although similar profiles in nose and flavor, this one couldn’t stand up to the Vortex. I think we agreed that, in retrospect, we should have reverse them. Still, a pleasant enough stout.

Bottle at the Williamsburg Gathering courtesy on Immy. Dark brown to near black pour. Nose is dark, roasted malts, soft coffee, dark chocolate and light dark fruity notes. Taste is more dark chocolate, dark fruits, soft, bitter coffee, and dark, roasted malts. The body on this was rather creamy and velvety. Very smooth. Medium overall. Ends with more dark roasted malts, dark chocolate, coffee and fading dark fruit notes.

22oz bottle, Thanks to Immy at Richmond Summer Gathering @ Williamsburg. Pours pitch black in color with brown head. Aroma chocolate, fruity and sweet malt. Taste of malt, fruity and coffee with dry finish.

Bottle. Opaque black-brown with short-lived tan head. Aroma of cocoa, carob, prune, and vanilla. Nice big mouthfeel that is not chewy. Fairly high carbonation takes it all over the mouth well. Leaves traces of really creamy cocoa, ganache, very robust with roasted malt finish and bittersweet chocolate. Lovely!

Bottle (22 oz. bomber purchased at the brewery). Pours opaque black with a somewhat fluffy brown head that, while thin, stays for the whole glass. Aroma is roasty, black coffee and rich dark cocoa fil the nose. Flavor is rich - again, there’s dark, rich chocolate and roasty black coffee, with a smoothness and subdued sweetness that is singular, and just the barest hint of alcohol. Finishes with an appropriate, very lightly acidic dryness that balances the beautiful, rich flavor. Palate is almost milkshake thick, with a deliciously light and creamy carbonation.

Yes this was a bomber and I will be sad to see them go 
Poured into a sniffer tan two finger head that turns to a great lacing in top of a rich black body 

Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, espresso and light amount of alcohol enter my nose 

The flavors on this brew are wicked good yes Im from Maine. Chocolate coffee and booze what more can a Yankee ask for 
Smooth comes to mind when thinking about the mouthfeel, rich and thick as well.

You can easily finish a bomber by yourself, especially on a cold New England night but it is much more fun to share. Buy the bombers while you can. Now for the 12 oz well If it ant broke dont fix it is all I can say and they tried to fix it. (Different yeast not bottled conditioned as well as different water)  It goes against everything that is down east in me to see what they have done to this brew. Ok enough ranting maybe the flatlander that bought this company will get the hint when the sales go south although that is where he is from

12 oz. bottle courtesy cdumler. Thanks Chris! Cola brown with a medium head. Decent lacing but not so good retention. Sweet malty aroma with notes of smoke, grain and coffee. Taste of slightly bitter grain and coffee. Medium to full bodied.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Trenton Marketplace (Trenton, ME). Arôme: Odeur très chocolatée avec une pointe de café. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence d’un moyen col beige foncé et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût très chocolaté avec avec une pointe de café et de vanille. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement crémeuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût très chocolaté avec une pointe fruitée. (Rating #1781)

Pours out black and leaves an excellent tan head and lacing behind. Smell was nice and roasty, plenty of cocoa as well. As I dug deeper I found remnants of earth, and a bit of some sort of a berry. Taste was earthy, sweet and definately roasty, but just didn’t seem all that awesome to me (older bottle?). Medium bodied, medium carbonation, dry roasty finish. Drinkability is fine, but didn’t keep bringing me back for more. I probably wouldn’t go out of my way for this one again.

This beer poured a blackish tan into a pint glass with zero light shining through. A vigorous pour resulted in several inches of thick, tan foam which slowly gave way to a ring of foam around the top of the beer. Not much lacing. 

Aromas are not that strong, but I do have a bit of a cold and am not picking up subtle aromas that I might otherwise smell. Even so, I pick up some chocolate and roasted malts. 

Taste is excellent. Roasted malts, hints of bittersweet chocolate and a slight bit of fruitiness rounds out the flavor. It is very well balanced. 

Mouthfeel is exceptional. Rich and thick but not syrupy or viscous. Slight carbonation cleanses the palate and leaves you wanting more.

Pours pitch black with a one inch tan head that showed great retention and a bit of lacing.  Smell is dominated by roasted coffee with a strong presence of sweet roasted malts and dark chocolate.  There are also some dark fruits in the nose, but very subtle along with some vanilla.  Taste follows the smell pretty consistently with a strong sweet malt blast up front with fresh roasted coffee and dark chocolate in the mix as well.  Mouthfeel is luxuriant for a stout - creamy and smooth with the perfect amount of carbonation.  Exceptional mouthfeel.  This is one of the best dry stouts I have ever tasted and can hold a candle with some of the best impy stouts Ive had.  Get your hands on this if you can.

Thanks to BrianK for introducing me to beer trading as this was his first trade, i only aiding in the financial aspect, i guess that was almost a year ago now.  Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a 2 finger light brown head.   Aroma is sweet chocolate malt, somewhat roasty, with little detectable etoh.  Flavor is sweet with chocolate yet creamy and some vanilla and finishes bittersweet. Great!

22 oz bomber purchased on a weekend trip to Maine. Pours a dark brown ( almost black ) with ruby edges.  Two finger creamy tan head with good lacing. Nose is malt, chocolate, and a hint of coffee. Mouthfeel is just about right. Heavy enough to be noticable, but not thick and oily. A little more carbonation than you usually think for a stout. Taste was a wonderful mix of malt, semi sweet chocolate, coffee, a hint of vanilla, & even a small hop presence. A very well balanced brew. As one of my fellow raters said " it doesnt try to be to big". That hits it right on the money.  Terrific brew.

Got this bottle on vacation.  very dark, with modesy creamy tan head.  Scents of malts and tar.  For me the level of carbonation is just right but of course high for a stout, and it helps balance out the sweetness.  Some vanilla notes
bottle,  dark brown to black color, no head to speak of,  bright, hoppy and a dry finish

Wasnt planning on drinking tonight but its St Patricks day so what the hell.

A- Couldnt imagine a stout looking much better than this. Pours a dark brown hue with a nice, fluffy, 2.5 finger, brownish head.

S- Smell is deep roasted malts with hints of coffee in the background.

T- I havent had a stout thats impressed me in quite a while but this one is definitely the first (of many hopefully). Very rich, choclatey, hints of coffee, incredibly well balanced.

M- Quite a bit of carbonation, medium viscosity (maybe a bit more viscous than average).

D- I was ready to trash this one as I normally dont like stouts but I have to say the balance in this one really does it for me. Its not trying to be too big, just a nice, incredibly balanced, rich stout.
Dark brown to black in color.  Opaque in look.  Coffee, roastiness, malts are in the smells.  Taste is much of the same as the aromas.  Slightly dry finish.

(22oz. bottle)  Pours a dark brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, light coffee, and some rye.  Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, and caramel malt with a somewhat creamy mouthfeel and dry finish.

Thanks to Drewbeerme for sharing this one.  Dark black almost opaque with creamy off-white head.  Aroma is dry powder cocoa with some roast.  Flavor is dry chocolate malt with nice malt profile.  Medium body with nice carbonation.  Very in style and nice.  Thanks Andrew!
22oz bottle. pours very dark with creamy off white head. nose and flavor of smooth bakers chocolate. great chocolate flavor and dry finish. one of the best dry stouts ive had.

Dark brown color with a big foamy tan head.  Aroma is roasty, chocolatey, and dosed with a bit of chocolate and spice.  Flavor is dry and roasty with some dark chocolate and a hint of coffee.  Medium bodied and smooth.  A really good dry stout.

Bottle courtesy of Wickedpete: Poured a deep black color stout with a nice foamy head with good retention and some nice lacing. Aroma of light roasted malt notes with some great black chocolate element. Taste is also dominated by some great roasted notes with some black chocolates notes with what appears to be some lactose. Full creamy body is probably one of the best that I have tasted in ages with a great level of carbonation for the style. I was really impressed by this one and definitely one of the best for this style.

2-22-08 bottle 

Black in color with a small white head that fades quickly.  Smell is subtle (a bit too much so) roasted malt and toffee.  Not a very "big" or bold flavor - some slight roasted hints are there.  Highly carbonated which doesnt exactly seem right.  Overall, pretty decent
Bottled. Aroma has chocolate malts and fruits. Black coloured with a medium, creamy, beige head. Taste is sweet, has bitterness, roast, dried fruits, (milk) chocolate. Good, smooth finish. Okay.
Dark color, medium off-white head. Aroma of chocolat, roasted malt, hint of rye, milk chocolat, slight fruity. Creamy taste, malty, roasted. Lacks some body though.

Bottle courtesy of Pastor.  Thanks!

Pours black with a light short lived light tan head.  Smell is dry, roasty, chocolate and coffee balanced very well.  Medium bodied with a slightly bubbly carbonation and flavors of roasty chocolate malt and light coffee.  Flavor is a touch thin but is very nice and drinkability is quite good.  Nice beer.
Bottle @ jbruss place. Strong aroma of chocolate, cardemom and coffee. Creamy, velvety flavor with coffee, milk chocolate. Lacks some body in the finish, but a quite likeable dry stout.

22oz from markgugs - thanks, Mark! A nice looking beer, dark with ruby glints. Initially quite an active head but it dies down quickly - not before giving out an appetizing aroma of chocolate malts. Hefty and satisfying, with a deep flavor (not especially complex) and a long lasting finish. Very nice dry stout, hope to try it again.

Wow, this beer reminds me of a really good porter.  Very dark and malty with a big helping of roasted malt and a little cocoa, this beer is a smooth drinker.  Fairly creamy for a dry stout as well.  Thicker than a porter, but thinner than an Impy.  

Really good little brew here.

2/02/2008:  Cadillac Mountain Stout has a thick and creamy mocha-colored head that sits on top of the very dark brown-colored beer like whipped cream.   The aroma is slightly dry and contains a nice blend of semi-sweet chocoate, weak coffee, roasted malt, and even a touch fo char.   The flavor has a fairly rich blend of caramelized and roasted malt with some dark fruit in the background.  The finish is more dry than the main flavor and has just a touch of bitterness and a nice roasted malt/mocha (more coffee-ish though) flavor.  The body is medium-full and creamy and goes down really smoothly.  This is a fine example of a Dry Stout at an excellent price (only $3.99+tx)!
1 pint 6 fl. oz. bottle (Brew #01935) from porterhouse.  Thanks Kevin.  Rating #190 for this beer...

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2008 Thanks to mkgrenwel fot the bottle. Dark brown pour with a medium head. Aroma of coffee, dark fruit (prunes and figs) and dark malt. A little chocolate in the taste, but oh so dry. Medium-heavy body. Finishes dry with a little bitter hops.

22oz bottle, courtesy of zathrus13.  Thanks, Jeff!  Pours a very dark, cherry cola color; khaki colored head with great retention and lacing, coating the glass.  Pleasant amounts of cocoa and nougat in the aroma; plenty of chocolate.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: plenty of milk chocolate, cocoa, and nougat upfront; a fair amount of sweetness; minimal hop bitterness surrounding the whole thing, but a reasonably tasty maltiness.  Lengthy, milk chocolate and cocoa in the finish; a bit chalky.

Provided by kmweaver. Dark brown body with a small beige head. The nose is fairly dry bakers chocolate with some light dark fruits and light molasses. The flavor is lightly sweet with caramel, chocolate and raisins. Medium body is round with moderate carbonation. Decent.
A bit over flavoered in the vannilla department, so unexpected.Smooth tecture but bitter semi-sweet chocolate finish.

text: Pours opaque black with mahogany hue and a tan frothy head that dies pretty quick. Nose is roasty with chocolate, a hint of coffee and a vanilla bean scent. Taste is nice and roasty, chocolate and bakers chocolate and a vanilla/toffee like finish with a little bitterness. Velvet in the mouth and not syrupy in any way. Nice carbonation. This is somewhat porter like in feel but has a lot of delicious stout taste. A perfect balance of flavor and body and a delight to sip. Could do another!

22oz Bomber

Recieved this bottle from scthaden, thank you. Cadillac Mountain Stout pours absolute black. When directly backlit deep mahogany highlights extend through the body. As I pour a one finger beige head forms and eventually falls to a generous crown. Leaves spotty lacing here and there.

The nose is a little faint on this one. The malts are on the border of being roasted and theres a generous helping of cocoa powder. A lactic creaminess comes around with each swirl of the glass. This bottle actually smells like it may still be a little green. 

The flavor is far superior to the aroma. The grains are roasted just to the point being slightly bitter. Coffee grounds add a touch of bitterness as well. The creaminess comes through mid-palate along with a mild dark fruitiness and the cocoa powder. I even seem to pick up a pinch of nuttiness on the finish. As this beer warms the complexities continue coming forward. An excellent tasting stout.

This is a medium bodied stout with a silky smooth mouthfeel. Glides through the mouth effortlessly. Finishes slightly dry letting some of the coffee ground and roasty bitterness shine through.

This is a stout you could sit down with and enjoy all night. A tasty stout I cant see myself tiring of.

Im glad I was finally able to try this beer. Ive been eyeing it up for awhile now and was finally able to set up a trade. A beer Id pick up often if locally available. Thanks for the opportunity Shannon.

12/14/07
Black colour with a small dense tan head. Light roasted, coffee bitter aroma with fruity notes. Malty, fruity and light roasted flavor with a dry, light bitter finish.

This is an old rating I found jotted on a piece of paper lying around the house.  It is a tasty brew with nice roastiness and nuttiness.  Thick, bubbly tan, big head thats slightly soapy.  The finish has some great cocoa notes.   Oatmeal in the flavor.  It is very smooth and has a pleasant lactose and honey sweetness.  Nice.
bottle. it has a black color with a medium head. the aroma is roasty. the taste is nice and easy. roasty and very smooth.

Beige foam that lasts, not much lacing. Black in color. Aroma is light, hinting of molasses and malt. Flavor is coffee, some chocolate, roasted malt, very smooth, barely any bitter. Full bodied beer with a creamy  texture , good carbonation.  Really good.

From a 22-oz. bottle from Central Maine--Poured a highly carbonated fuzzy beige head that soon dissipated. The body revealed a deep dark black-brown and slightly amber body. Fruit and caramel notes predominated by chocolate flavors. Perhaps this one sat too long on the shelf, but it was still nice.  Wish I could have found it on tap, but Bar Harbor is pretty dead come October.

In short: One of the best small stout out there.  Very roasted and focussing on drinkability
How: Mtl-crew beer-and-spagatt tasting.  Bottle from Yowie
The look: Brown-black body with a very small tan head.
In long: Heres a crisp highly roasted and highly drinkable stout.  Roasted coffee beans and distant chocolate are there too.  Almost nothing in the way of fruity notes.  Perfect balance with hops that have more of a drying than a bittering effect.  The high carbonation level just adds to the drinkability.  No it is not a complex beer, it is a marvellously simple beer.  I could drink pints and pints of that stuff and still want more the day after.  An easy name to remember too cause it truly is the Cadillac of session stouts.
Pours a dark brown with a smaller off white bubbly off white head.  Aroma of milk chocolate, roasted malts, light coffee.  Flavor of roasted malts, bitter chocolate and coffee.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2008 This stout is as magnificent as the mountain its named for.  Definitely the best Ive ever had, regular, imperial or otherwise.  The malt balance was fantastic, with the right amount of smokiness and roasted flavors.  Nothing too overpowering, nothing left out.  Definitely worth a trip to Maine.
22 oz. bottle. deep dark brown with a roasty malt aroma. thick chocolate at first taste, dry slight bitterness in the finish. Excellent drinking.

Bottle from porterhouse - thanks, Kevin!  Chocolate and toasty-roast aroma.  Pitch pour with a soapy, small-bubbled light brown head.  Crisp, sharp attack, dry and roasty taste with nice burned notes and light bitterness.  Faint strokes of caramel and hops, with a dash of lactose.  Carbonation is a bit of a negative here for me - a little too intense - but after sitting a while, the sting subsides and allows the rich chocolate notes to shine through.  Aftertaste is dry, lightly toasted, with slight sour notes.  Stylish!  Medium body but extremely, extremely drinkable; the contents of the bomber just disappeared, where did they go?
Bottle. Pours almost black with a tan head. Feels kinda dusty with notes of fruits, berries, chocolate and caramel. Kinda onesided and not too well balanced.
Dark brown/black, with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate and roasted malt. Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, with hints of dark fruit and caramel.  Nicely done.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of roast, chocolate, malts, and a little pine.  Poured black in color with a medium tan head that diminished.  No lacing.  Opaque.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter flavor.  Tastes of chocolate, roasting, malt, and a little coffee.  Medium body.  Tingly texture.  Lively carbonation.  Chocolate malt finish.  Overall, a nice Stout.

Bottle from Capones.  Deep brownish pour that shows ruby through direct light and a big khaki head.  Aroma is roasty malt, chocoff,figs, nuts, some molasses.  Tastes roasty dark malty, fairly dry, with chocoff and slight fig and brown sugar notes.  Medium palate heft with a decent complexity.

Courtesy The_Epeeist. Black/brown, brown edges. 1/2cm tan head. Roasty malt, light smoke, chocolate, light coffee, and a modest dose of bitter hops. Aroma is more intense than the flavor. Body is medium, balanced. Very drinkable. Solid.

Well what do you know, all that time and New England and I have this in North Carolina, courtesy of TURDFERGUSON. Good aroma, cardbosrd/paper, milk chocolate, minor fruitiness, berry. Dark brownish black color, good head that faded quick. Bitter sweet flavor, chocolate got bigger. Some banana shows up. red berry. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, smooth dry finish. Tasty stout,  I liked the differences that happened between aroma and flavor.
